headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to M&I’s fourth quarter 2009 results conference call. My name is Stephanie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode. A brief question-and-answer session will follow the formal present
componenttext:
Welcome to M&I’s fourth quarter 2009 results conference call. My name is Stephanie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode. A brief question-and-answer session will follow the formal presentation. As a reminder this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
It is now my pleasure to introduce Dave Urban, Director of Investor Relations at M&I. Sir you may begin your conference.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you and welcome to M&I’s fourth quarter 2009 earnings conference call. The presenters for today’s call will be Mark Furlong, our Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Smith, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the fourth quarter financial r
componenttext:
Thank you and welcome to M&I’s fourth quarter 2009 earnings conference call. The presenters for today’s call will be Mark Furlong, our Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Smith, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the fourth quarter financial results. At the end of our prepared remarks, Mark, Greg, and Mark Hogan, our Chief Credit Officer, will be available for your question.
Before we begin let me make a few preliminary comments. If you have not read our earnings release you may access it along with supplemental financial information from the Investor Relations section of our website at www.micorp.com. Also, before we start, I would like to mention the comments made during this call contain forward-looking statements concerning M&I’s future operations and financial results.
Such statements are subject to important factors, which could cause M&I’s actual results to differ materially from those anticipated by the forward-looking statements. These factors are described in M&I’s most recent Form 10-K and M&I’s other SEC filings. Such factors are incorporated herein by reference. For a reconciliation of any non-GAAP financial measures mentioned in this presentation, to the most comparable financial measures calculated in accordance with GAAP. Please refer to M&I’s website at www.micorp.com.
Now I will turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Dave. As you can see from our results, we continue to remain aggressive in dealing with tough credit issues. Though elevated levels of charge-offs will continue for the next couple quarters, barring something unforeseen taking place in the economy
componenttext:
Thanks Dave. As you can see from our results, we continue to remain aggressive in dealing with tough credit issues. Though elevated levels of charge-offs will continue for the next couple quarters, barring something unforeseen taking place in the economy we do expect charge-offs to start to decline in 2010.
We will continue to have some relationships that we need to work through the end of the recession, but the likelihood of a real estate project surviving today is a great deal different than two years ago. We are most likely at a turning point in credit quality though another quarter or two is needed to validate that condition.
As Greg Smith will review with you in a couple of minutes, early stage delinquency continues to improve, such as loans 39 days to 80 days the delinquent are now at the lowest level since 2007. This is probably our best gauge for future charge-offs. A great deal of attention is being devoted to what may occur with commercial real estate this year and over the next two to three years.
Although our delinquency in commercial real estate is higher than in 2007 the trend is toward a decline in delinquency the last two quarters. We remain optimistic, though focused on this portfolio particularly as we finish the review of all loans greater than $1 million in December.
We have no expectations that our commercial real estate portfolio will perform in any way comparable to what we’ve seen with construction and development. Our sentiments rest there due to the small average size of our loans, our concentration in the Midwest, and the extent of cash flow stabilization in this book of business. I’m sure we’ll have some issues overtime, but we expect them to be manageable.
As we move into 2010 we’ve intended to leave no struggling assets unaddressed. In addition to significant charge-offs on our portfolio over the last two years we’ve sold $2 billion of underperforming loans. We will continue to sell these loans, but we expect the pace to slow. We saw some improvement in pricing this quarter which is to be expected as real estate values begin to stabilize.
We feel the same way about properties we’ve taken into owned real estate on the commercial side of REO we have three completed projects in the process of being leased up that aggregated by $80 million to be just written down by 25%. On the consumer side, the small number of homes we own are being carried at approximately 62% of unpaid balance and the residential lots are being carried at 30% of unpaid balance.
The point is say that is read that we are addressing every matter in the same manner. We glad to put these last two years behind is and though the economies still create some uncertainty we feel like we are well positioned to remain strong as the credit cycle winds down. There are several positive indicators about the underlying strength of M&I and Greg will share some of the metrics of these non-credit aspects of our business to reinforce our sentiments.
With that, let me turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark and thank you everyone for joining us today. By now you have had an opportunity to see our press release and supplemental financial information. We have included detailed credit quality slides on our website. You may want to have these pri
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark and thank you everyone for joining us today. By now you have had an opportunity to see our press release and supplemental financial information. We have included detailed credit quality slides on our website. You may want to have these printed out and available for our credit quality discussion.
Although our fourth quarter results continue to reflect the challenging operating environment that has confronted banks. Our results provide us building confidence and better recovery is underway at M&I. Our credit quality trends continue to benefit from our aggressive approach to non-performing loan identification and resolution.
As is shown by continued favorable trends in loans going on to non-performing status, continued improvement in early stage delinquencies, which decreased for the third consecutive quarter, continued improvement in total nonperforming loans which decreased for the second consecutive quarter.
The important items to focus on to better understand our fourth quarter performance include the following. We have continued our aggressive steps to address the largest risks in our loan portfolio, including our construction and development business, even though these steps continue to be the primary reason for our loss in the quarter.
In addition, we transferred $170 million of larger previously classified as renegotiated loans to non-performing status as our review showed core performance on these properties deteriorated. We will discuss these loans in more detail later in this call.
Despite the migration of these renegotiated loans, non-performing loans were down over $200 million this quarter, which reflects the impact of our continued aggressive non-performing loan workout and disposition strategies. In comparison to the prior quarter, non-performing loan inflows were down 8%, when adjusted for the previously renegotiated loans mentioned a moment ago. For the quarter our early stage loan delinquencies, those loans past due 30 to 89 days, declined by over 15%, since September to the lowest level since 2007.
As we have noted previously, we are increasingly comfortable that the pattern of large commercial real estate construction and development charge offs in Arizona is largely behind us. Since year end 2007, this portfolio has contracted by nearly 80% and is now under $300 million.
Although, we do not believe our construction and development issues are completely behind us, we are encouraged that total non-accrual C&D loans contracted for the third quarter in a row. Our non-performing loans continue to decline. Our portfolio of C&D loans on non-accrual amounts to approximately $800 million, down approximately $180 million from September 30. This decrease is largely attributable to the Arizona market.
We have increased our reserve to 3.35% of total loans, or nearly $1.5 billion and continue to make progress toward our goal of reducing our concentration of construction and development loans, which now stand at 12.5% of our loan portfolio versus 18% at the end of 2008.
For the quarter, we benefited from $46 million in after tax gains from security sales and tendering of our own debt securities. These gains are offset by further aggressive steps in non-performing asset resolution. Our Wealth Management Division continued to grow revenues as well as assets under both management and administration this quarter, reaching record highs for both. We continue to have a capital base well above any regulatory capital thresholds.
At quarter end, our tangible common equity ratio was 8 .2%, and our tier 1 risk based capital ratio is estimated to be 11.1%. During the quarter, we realized 13 bays points of net interest margin expansion, reflecting continued success in improving our funding and lending profiles and the effect of fewer loans becoming nonperforming. We finished 2009 with 106% loan to deposit ratio down from 132% just two years ago.
Now for some additional insights into the quarter and we’ll start with the net interest margin; our net interest margin increased by 13 basis points on a linked quarter basis to 2.95%. During the fourth quarter, our net interest margin benefited from credit quality improvement and the restructuring and/or retiring of certain debt instruments.
Despite recent asset quality improvements, our margin continues to be negatively impacted by non-performing assets. The negative impact is 25 basis points in total and 13 basis points over the fourth quarter of 2007. We expect that the net interest margin will trend upward slightly for the near term as we anticipate additional favorable results from the restructuring activities late in the quarter and further improvements in credit quality.
Like the industry in general, we expect to be challenged by competitive pricing, the impact of deposit and loan pricing floors, the movement of new and existing deposits into lower spread higher yielding products, wholesale funding spreads, and, of course, the yield curve. There continue to be many variables that impact margin. It is difficult to project this one data point given the current interest rate volatility occurring in the market.
Now, moving on to wealth management, in spite of market volatility, revenues increased 5% on a linked quarter basis and 9% compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. Expanding sales, enhanced investment products and investment performance generated the improved results. Sales pipelines continue to build across our divisions, especially in our institutional businesses, which include our retirement services not for profit, and outsourcing lines.
Assets under Management, reached $33 billion, up 8% compared to the end of 2008. Our Assets under Administration rose to $122 billion, or 17% greater than the same period a year ago. Our asset management acquisitions continue to perform well, Delta, Taplin, Canida & Habacht since experienced new asset additions and growth of existing relationships during the quarter.
Our brokerage and insurance division continued to experience good sales flows during the quarter as investors position their portfolios for 2010. Revenues were up 1% on a linked quarter basis and up 6% compared to the same quarter last year, reflecting improved investor confidence and greater coverage by our financial advisers.
From an expense standpoint, total non-interest expense amounted to $409 million in the fourth quarter consistent with the third quarter. Expenses for non-performing assets and other credit related items were relatively unchanged compared to last quarter at $69 million. These are largely related to collection efforts and carrying costs for non-performing assets.
Although, our reported efficiency ratio was 67%, when adjusted for these items and other credit related expenses, we view our core efficiency ratio to be 56.7%, down 1% from the prior quarter. Nonetheless, particularly in the current operating environment, M&I will continue to be very focused on maintaining our historical expense discipline.
Now, moving onto our credit quality trends, non-performing loans decreased for the second consecutive quarter, resulting in our lowest level of nonperforming loans since the end of 2008. When coupled with continued improvement in early stage delinquencies, these trends support our aggressive approach to problem credit resolution. Continuing with that approach, we increased our loan loss reserves, which now stand at $1.5 billion, or 3.35% of total loans.
Our commercial non-construction commercial real estate and consumer portfolios continue to have non-performing characteristics better than the bank as a whole while our construction and development related loans continue to show the stresses of the national housing markets. This stress continues to be most apparent in the Arizona market, where home prices have fallen over 50% from their peak in June of 2006.
Coming into 2010, we continue to anticipate a relative stabilization in non-performing loan trends, reflecting sustained improvement in early stage delinquencies, reduced inflows, and continued aggressive strategies to workout or sell non-performing credits. We were pleased that our non-performing loans again decreased for the quarter. Moving into 2010, we have strengthening confidence that we will see continued credit quality improvements.
For the quarter, we realized net charge-offs of $572 million, and we provided $639 million for loan losses. Although these are higher than we initially expected, these levels reflect our continued efforts to proactively reduce our exposure to problem relationships. Importantly, we don’t believe the charge-offs and provision for this quarter are indicative for what we expect for 2010.
Our quarter end reserve was 3.35% of period end total loans, which is an increase of $67 million from the prior quarter end. In addition to building the allowance, we’ve identified the specific loss content in non-accrual loans over $1 million and marked them to net realizable value with either a specific reserve or charge-off.
As shown in slide six, M&I has conducted a specific impairment analysis of $1.4 billion, or 70% of total non-performing loans to quantify potential impairment. On average, 27% of the unpaid principal balance of these loans has been charged off. Through building the allowance and aggressively writing down problem loans, M&I post a solid adjusted reserve coverage ratio of 191%.
As we look forward, we expect to continue taking aggressive steps to resolve our non-performing loans, the proceeds from which will be redeployed in our business. As in prior quarters, the largest proportion of charge offs, approximately 52%, were associated with the Arizona and Florida market places.
As shown on slide 31 the net charge offs by geographic location were $187 million for Arizona, and $108 million for Florida. Otherwise, charge offs were rather diversified from a geographic perspective. As expected, we are seeing a shift in Arizona charge offs away from our credits toward smaller retail related credits.
Discussing our non-performing loan trends, during the quarter, our non-performing loans decreased $205 million, which is 9% below last quarter and 15% below second quarter. For the quarter, we sold $143 million in larger stress construction and development loans. In addition, we sold a $70 million pool of non-performing or seriously delinquent single family mortgage loans resulting in a $35 million net charge off.
Like our last non-performing residential loan sale, over 60% of the underlying loans are in Arizona. As in the past, we have moved aggressively to identify potential non-performing loans and the associated loss content. This is supported by the following. 25% of our non-performing loans are current or past due less than 30 days up from 16% last quarter.
Of our loans past due 30 to 89 days, which we consider our early stage delinquencies, our $170 million are already non-performing. 34%, or $687 million of our non-performing loans, are past due less than 90 days. We have already realized partial charge offs of $810 million against our non-performing loans, represent ago 28% haircut.
Another way to look at our partial charge offs is that it represents a 52% write-down on specific non-performing loans, where a direct write-down was deemed necessary. A few comments on our construction and development portfolios, within our loan portfolios, we continue to focus on our construction and development categories, particularly residential related.
Please note on slide eight that we have segmented our commercial construction portfolio between C&I related and housing related. This slide highlights the continued strong credited quality profile of the non-housing component of the commercial construction portfolio. Less than half of our commercial construction portfolio is related too housing.
As of quarter end, we have $80 million in construction and development loans on non-performing status representing 39% of our total non-performing loans. As shown in slide 33, of these non-performing construction and development loans, 50% are in the Arizona and Florida markets. On average, these loans are already heavily reserved or charged down. Clearly our issues remain concentrated in these markets.
To provide a little more granularity on our portfolio of larger construction and development projects, the following may be helpful. We have 27 loans greater than $5 million on non-accrual status. Only nine of these are in excess of $10 million and only one of these is in excess of $20 million.
We have seen some stabilization in the residential land portfolio during the fourth quarter as non-performing loans have fallen $64 million. This portfolio is shown in slides 38 and 39. We have $1.6 billion in residential land loans to individuals and developers, $870 million or 55% are located in Arizona zip codes. The bulk of the Arizona loans, two thirds are in Maricopa County.
The loans to individuals in the Arizona portfolio are relatively modest in size with an average balance of approximately $174,000. We continue to refresh both FICO scores and LTV’s for the Arizona portfolio. Individual FICO scores average 736 at the time of origination and for the performing loans remain above 720 today.
Although we anticipate that our non-performing loans in the Arizona residential land portfolio will remain elevated. We believe we will benefit from the fact that we first tightened our underwriting standards in mid 2005 and ceased new money originations in 2008. Residential lot loans to individuals and developers account for $259 million of non-performing loans of which 47% are based in Arizona zip codes.
With regard to conventional mortgages, our portfolio continues to show that individuals are feeling continued economic stress. As we’ve noted before, we maintained our underwriting discipline through the cycle, have never originated subprime loans and have avoided many of the more risky loan products.
During the quarter, our non-performing residential loans decreased to $206 million or 4.2% of the residential mortgage portfolio. These trends highlight the benefit of our non-performing residential loan sales completed in December and July. We continue to aggressively monitor and manage this portfolio. Just a couple of comments on our consumer loan trends as the overall consumer portfolio has maintained its non-performing loan levels below those of the overall bank.
As of quarter end, only 1.4% of consumer loans were on non-performing status. As we have noted in the past, our credit quality experience with this portfolio has benefited from our historical practice of selling much of our production as we did in 2005 and 2006. Looking forward, consumer non-accruals, including both residential and home equity, are likely to remain elevated reflecting continued consumer stress although we expect that our ultimate losses will remain better than industry averages.
With regard to the commercial loan portfolio, during the course of the fourth quarter, we realized $85 million of net charge-offs in our C&I portfolio, these charge-offs are geographically disbursed. Generally our commercial portfolio has performed relatively well during this cycle, while still showing the effect of the economy. In addition, we realized a decrease of $61 million in nonperforming C&I loans.
A brief comment on bank holding company loans, as of year end, we continue to retain a portfolio of approximately $550 million of which 11% is non-performing and against which we have reserves of 17%. We are adequately reserved, but will continue to evaluate this portfolio critically. Going forward, based on the rapidly changing landscape for banks and the loss of market synergies caused by the spin-off of Metavante.
M&I’s correspondent banking strategy has been redefined to include only core relationships within our banking footprint with a primary focus on fee based activities going forward. With regard to our non-construction commercial real estate portfolio, we have $13.6 billion outstanding with $3.6 billion in multifamily and $9.3 billion in business real estate.
As shown on slide 16, our business real estate portfolio is generally concentrated in our core Midwest markets, two/thirds, with only 17% in our combined Florida and Arizona markets and another 3% in other higher risk markets, 37% of this portfolio is owner occupied. In the fourth quarter, we saw our non-performing loans in the non-construction commercial real estate category increase $75 million to 4.3%.
Contributing to this increase is the review of renegotiated loans that we noted earlier in the call. We performed a rigorous review of our commercial division renegotiated loans and found that the performance of certain related properties had deteriorated to a point where we felt non-accrual status was more appropriate. With this determination, we moved a $170 million to non-accrual status.
In addition, we are carrying the loans on our books at 44% of unpaid principal balance, through either partial charge-offs or specific reserves. A few comments on our accruing renegotiated loans. Over the past quarter, we have seen a $142 million decrease in accruing renegotiated loans to a total of $793 million. This decrease is largely result of previously discussed review of certain relationships.
On the consumer side, the vast majority of these loans continue to be related to home, land or construction loans to individuals. At quarter end, these categories accounted for approximately $647 million or 82% of the total. Within the consumer sector, our restructured loan delinquency trends continue to perform better than national averages.
Over the next few quarters, we continue to expect non-performing loan and real estate owned balances to remain elevated above historical averages, reflecting broader economic stress, though we anticipate inflows will continue to slow. We specifically anticipate that the inflows of larger construction credits are passed their peak.
As I noted in discussion slide six, through increasing the reserve and aggressively writing down problem loans, M&I has an adjusted reserve coverage ratio of 191%. We will continue to evaluate the opportunity for further sales of non-performing assets and weigh the opportunity versus the cost to keep those assets for a period of time.
Sometimes the best resolution will be to take the underlying property to maximize our interest, which will cause in creases to REO for a period of time. This quarter, our REO increased to $431 million, and this is consistent with previous expectations. We have seven commercial properties over $100 million. We continue to expect that REO balances will increase going forward and view this as a natural progression as we gain control of projects and move toward ultimate resolutions. 
A few final comments on credit quality, stresses in the national housing and commercial real estate market will continue to affect us, and we will continue to address them proactively. We have and will continue to take aggressive steps to resolve our non-performing situations. Nonetheless, should the economy continue to deteriorate beyond our current expectations, our losses could continue.
Our non-performing loans continue to be concentrated in the housing construction related components of the commercial and residential real estate portfolios particularly in our Arizona, Florida, and correspondent businesses. Despite a recent increase in Florida, we continue to believe our larger C&D challenges in the Florida and Arizona markets are behind us.
Although, we are not immune from consumer deterioration, we believe our residential and consumer portfolios will continue to perform better than the industry as a whole, and also recall that our credit card portfolio is relatively small with less than $300 million of outstandings. We will continue to maintain a strong reserve coverage ratio and we’ll continue to aggressively write down problem loans.
We remain committed to returning M&I to a level of solid credit quality and are hopeful that our declines in non-performing loans, non-performing loan inflows, and early stage delinquencies are all early indicators of achieving this goal. Changing focus to the organic balance sheet trends compared to the same quarter in 2008.
Fourth quarter 2009 average loans were $45 billion, which is 4.9 billion or 10% lower than the fourth quarter 2008. C&I loans decreased on average by $2.2 billion or 14% as we are seeing lower line utilization and seasonal borrowing from existing customers than in prior years.
Moving into 2010, we expect C&I balance to continue contracting until the economic recovery takes stronger hold. On a linked quarter basis, C&I loans contracted $960 million or 6.8%. Across all of our construction and development categories, we have seen approximately $3.7 billion or 38% contraction, since the fourth quarter of last year.
This is consistent with our broader goal of reducing our total construction and development portfolio to less than 10% of total loans. At quarter end, construction and development loans account for 12.5% of total loans, down from a high of 22.6% in the third quarter of 2007.
Non-construction commercial real estate loans increased on average by $1.6 billion or nearly 13% in comparison to the same quarter last year. This reflects the natural progression of projects to completion and lease up, most of which occurred earlier in 2009. Own a linked quarter basis loans in this category were essential flat.
Commercial real estate volumes are soft in all categories, reflecting the economy. This is translated into minimal investor activity in new construction projects with medical office being the least impacted, lack of availability of any financing is significantly impacting this marketplace.
Retail continues to soften and is expected to do so through 2010 as many retailers have cutback expansion plans. Many retailers are demanding rent concessions on existing leases potentially impacting our customers. Office continues to soften in all markets. Job losses significantly impacted this segment in 2009 and are anticipated to do so in 2010.
Hospitality softened with the economy in the second half of 2009, and is expected to remain soft. Together, these factors lead to our expectation that our non-construction commercial real estate portfolio balances will be relatively flat for 2010.
On the deposit side, we have seen good underlying dynamics this year, with average deposit balances up nearly $1 billion dollars versus the fourth quarter of 2008. Non-interest bearing deposits increased $1.9 billion compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. This increase is a turbulent part to low interest rate environment and continued confidence in M&I.
As we have discussed before, we have reconfigured many of our deposit product offerings. The benefit of these changes are shown by the $1.6 billion of growth in savings deposits and the $1.6 billion of growth in NOW balances since the fourth quarter of last year. In addition, we have benefited from an improved deposit mix as our time balance has declined by over $2 billion.
A few final comments, as we move into the first quarter of 2010, and to reiterate comments made earlier, we expect our financial results to reflect the benefits of aggressive credit steps that we have taken, but also the challenges of broader financial markets.
As you are aware, every economic cycle brings its own set of challenges. This economic cycle has been marked by rapid deterioration followed by more recent stabilization in general economic conditions, a challenging and prolonged low interest rate environment, competitive pricing pressures on many loan and deposit products, and a dramatic downturn in the national and residential housing marks.
As we move forward in this economic cycle, we will continue to benefit from the strength of our balance sheet, the dedication of our employees, and the diversification of our franchise.
This concludes our prepared remarks. Joining me now are Mark Furlong, our CEO, and Mark Hogan, Chief Credited Officer. They can help answer questions. Operator, you may open the line for questions, please.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator Instructions) Your first question comes from Craig Siegenthaler - Credit Suisse.
componenttext: (Operator Instructions) Your first question comes from Craig Siegenthaler - Credit Suisse.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: First just a high level question on reserve methodology, given that your NPLs have improved for three straight quarters. Can you talk about maybe why reserves are still building at a fairly steep rate? It looks conservative for investor perspective, but g
componenttext:
First just a high level question on reserve methodology, given that your NPLs have improved for three straight quarters. Can you talk about maybe why reserves are still building at a fairly steep rate? It looks conservative for investor perspective, but given that your high severity NPLs, a lot of the construction horizontal loans have just passed the pipeline.
When do you expect provisions to start trending under charge-offs and allowing the reserve to start reducing? Is regulatory discussion is one other reasons that you’re still building the reserve here?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’ll take the second question first, and that the answer to that is, no. We work well with the regulators, but our methodology is what we work through own a quarterly basis, and just answering your first question, the reserve build that we’re seeing r
componenttext:
I’ll take the second question first, and that the answer to that is, no. We work well with the regulators, but our methodology is what we work through own a quarterly basis, and just answering your first question, the reserve build that we’re seeing right now is really a pressure that results primarily from the FAS 5 or historical loss rates, where the current quarters, if we’re in a 2.5 or a five-year average loss rate, the current quarters rates are much higher than the quarters that are dropping off at the end.
So what we need to see is, we think we need a couple more quarters where we see the portfolio trends continue to improve, and we’ve been fairly consistent with saying that, we believe in the third quarter is when we’ll start seeing the pressure, a downward pressure on the reserve and at that point we’ll look at what the portfolio looks like and the historical loss rates will have to come down. We’ll start adjusting them downward based on what our assessment is relative to the inherent risk in the remaining portfolio.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then just a second question, kind of a funding question. It looks like your non-interest bearing deposits declined in the last quarter. Overall, deposits were okay, but just wonder what kind of drove that, was it client demand from your clients or higher
componenttext: Then just a second question, kind of a funding question. It looks like your non-interest bearing deposits declined in the last quarter. Overall, deposits were okay, but just wonder what kind of drove that, was it client demand from your clients or higher interest and higher yields or what was kind of pushing that?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Craig, really that relates to two specific relationships that drove that, because when you look at the period end, it’s really the period end balances of DDA where you see that contrast. We had one large deposit come in for a very short period of time a
componenttext: Craig, really that relates to two specific relationships that drove that, because when you look at the period end, it’s really the period end balances of DDA where you see that contrast. We had one large deposit come in for a very short period of time at the end of the third quarter and then those proceeds were dispersed to the various recipients of the proceeds. So, that accounts for one component and then there was also a large depositor of ours that was acquired in the fourth quarter and their cash balances came down as part of that acquisition, but otherwise, the fundamental trends are very consistent with what we’ve seen in the past.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Matthew O’Connor - Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Matthew O’Connor - Deutsche Bank.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The last few quarters you’ve had this combination of strong deposit growth, declining loans and you’ve been using that to payoff of wholesale funding, which is helping out loan to deposit ratios you mentioned earlier, but assuming some of the trends c
componenttext: The last few quarters you’ve had this combination of strong deposit growth, declining loans and you’ve been using that to payoff of wholesale funding, which is helping out loan to deposit ratios you mentioned earlier, but assuming some of the trends continues in deposits and there’s still some decline in loans from here, how should we think about positioning of the balance sheet going forward in terms of will you continue to payoff debt or liquidity we will you add some carry trade, given how steep the curve is right now?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, as we think about our funding profile and our liquidity profile, we continue to really focus on maintaining not only sufficient liquidity, but excess liquidity. Markets are certainly more favorable than they’ve been, but they certainly are
componenttext:
First of all, as we think about our funding profile and our liquidity profile, we continue to really focus on maintaining not only sufficient liquidity, but excess liquidity. Markets are certainly more favorable than they’ve been, but they certainly aren’t what they once were, so we’re going to continue to position ourselves to being very liquid.
In addition, as we think about our profile, we continue to really think about investing shorter as opposed to longer, because we think the opportunity that will present itself to reinvest the cash that comes off shorter investments, when you think out, let’s say two years on the time horizon, will be a very attractive opportunity for investments at that point in time.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then just separately, I think you’ve had a moratorium on foreclosures for several months and I believe it was just extended for another few months. Do you have a sense of how that is impacting the charge-off and NPA trends right now?
componenttext: Then just separately, I think you’ve had a moratorium on foreclosures for several months and I believe it was just extended for another few months. Do you have a sense of how that is impacting the charge-off and NPA trends right now?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Generally this has been a very it’s been an important program. It’s been an important way in which we’re working with our customers and our communities. That said the overall impact has certainly been within very manageable levels of us continuing t
componenttext: Generally this has been a very it’s been an important program. It’s been an important way in which we’re working with our customers and our communities. That said the overall impact has certainly been within very manageable levels of us continuing to sustain this. In terms of number of loans that have actually gone successfully into the foreclosure moratorium, we’re still looking at something that’s around 400 or 450 through our footprint. So, in that sense, it may have some effect on provision in charge-offs, but nothing substantial.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010

componenttext: Yes, I do, in terms of the Tier 1 common ratio, our estimate of that for the quarter is going to be about 7.5%.

componenttext: Your next question comes from Kevin St. Pierre - Bernstein.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I looked at last quarter’s presentation, the same metrics, the lifetime charge-offs were 23% of unpaid principal. This quarter, they moved up to 31%. Is there something that changed the view, or is it the addition of the $170 million in CRE restructu
componenttext: If I looked at last quarter’s presentation, the same metrics, the lifetime charge-offs were 23% of unpaid principal. This quarter, they moved up to 31%. Is there something that changed the view, or is it the addition of the $170 million in CRE restructured loans?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It would not be the addition of the $170 million. We did add additional reserves for those, but they were not included in the charge-offs. So, the charge-offs would just have been, again, aggressively approaching the portfolio and marking them to we think
componenttext: It would not be the addition of the $170 million. We did add additional reserves for those, but they were not included in the charge-offs. So, the charge-offs would just have been, again, aggressively approaching the portfolio and marking them to we think is the appropriate level of valuations.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Terry McEvoy - Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Terry McEvoy - Oppenheimer.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your credit related non-interest expense is $69 million, $70 million a quarter over the last two quarters. Could you talk about, where you see those expenses headed in 2010? Then maybe remind me in ‘06 or ‘07, what was the quarterly run rate for those
componenttext: Your credit related non-interest expense is $69 million, $70 million a quarter over the last two quarters. Could you talk about, where you see those expenses headed in 2010? Then maybe remind me in ‘06 or ‘07, what was the quarterly run rate for those types of expenses to kind of get a feel fore a more normal environment?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, just in terms of $70 million in the third quarter, $69 million this quarter, to be fair, $69 million probably came in a little bit higher than we were anticipating for the quarter, but as we continued to be aggressive chasing resolution woun
componenttext:
First of all, just in terms of $70 million in the third quarter, $69 million this quarter, to be fair, $69 million probably came in a little bit higher than we were anticipating for the quarter, but as we continued to be aggressive chasing resolution wound up driving some of that. I think as we look forward, there’s a couple of factors that lead to us believe these numbers will be coming down.
Number one, as the loan trends continue to improve as well as new non-performing loan trend formation continues to improve that will certainly just stem what’s going into the pipeline. The other thing is I think, that we would expect is going to help us out here is as home prices stabilize throughout the country, we’re now finding our marks on ORE or loans held for sale are holding up better.
When you think about the type of price depreciation that we’ve had in housing over the last three years and the rapid descent of that, you could have had a piece of property that was well marked at the end of one quarter, but if you had the continued trend of home prices going down, you would have had an incremental mark the next quarter. So more stability in real estate prices is going to help us get the mark right the first time for the life of the loan, which, therefore means the ORE expenses should come down.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a second question, could you talk about M&I’s ability interest in FDIC assisted transaction, especially in and around the Chicago market? In the past, you’ve always set’s so competitive you don’t feel the need to be there, but as more and mor
componenttext: Just a second question, could you talk about M&I’s ability interest in FDIC assisted transaction, especially in and around the Chicago market? In the past, you’ve always set’s so competitive you don’t feel the need to be there, but as more and more banks fail, hopefully that eases some of the competition. Do you see that opening the door for M&I to have a sizable presence that in market?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the second part of that question first. Our view of Chicago has not changed. It continues to be a savage competitive dynamic in that market. We’ll let others fight that out. In terms of FDIC deals, our interest in FDIC deals has cooled a lit
componenttext:
Let me take the second part of that question first. Our view of Chicago has not changed. It continues to be a savage competitive dynamic in that market. We’ll let others fight that out. In terms of FDIC deals, our interest in FDIC deals has cooled a little bit for the moment.
As we are seeing these signs of credit quality stabilization or turn that is something we’re going to continue to be focused on. In addition, we’re going through a number of a variety of system type upgrades and improvements throughout the franchise, and we’re at the point where we want to make sure we get that right.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Tony Davis - Stifel Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Tony Davis - Stifel Nicolaus.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up here, I wonder if you could give us the composition of the deferred tax assets Greg, at year end, i.e., NOLs, timing difference, whatever it is, maybe some color on your thoughts about that asset with discussion you’ve had with your aud
componenttext: Just a follow-up here, I wonder if you could give us the composition of the deferred tax assets Greg, at year end, i.e., NOLs, timing difference, whatever it is, maybe some color on your thoughts about that asset with discussion you’ve had with your auditors or regulators, anything new there?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’m happy to go through some of that. In terms of the different building blocks, I don’t have those at my fingertips today, Tony. I’m happy to discuss those with you, though. In terms of how we look at the deferred tax asset, certainly as we’ve in
componenttext:
I’m happy to go through some of that. In terms of the different building blocks, I don’t have those at my fingertips today, Tony. I’m happy to discuss those with you, though. In terms of how we look at the deferred tax asset, certainly as we’ve indicated before, as we came up to year end, we were going to have to give a particularly thorough review.
We have gone through that process and found that given where we are, based on exactly the same types of fact pattern and logic that we’ve discussed these in past continue to find that our deferred tax asset is an asset that does not require any valuation allowance against it. So a lot of that comes from, again items such as projected utilization of it, deemphasizing a large business line, in this case the construction and development component. So in that sense, our logic has continues to be the same.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: You have extended the moratorium twice. I think you sold now, what, two $70 million blocks, and I think the renegotiated real estate is sold around $400 million. So I guess I’ll ask one, approximately what proportion of the Arizona, especially real esta
componenttext:
You have extended the moratorium twice. I think you sold now, what, two $70 million blocks, and I think the renegotiated real estate is sold around $400 million. So I guess I’ll ask one, approximately what proportion of the Arizona, especially real estate has been renegotiated?
Secondly, what are you seeing in terms of re-default rates today on renegotiated loans, and I guess maybe Mark should answer this one, just some sense of what inning it is in that entire resolution process?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: There’s a lot in those questions, but let me just stay with the delinquency rate on the renegotiated debt in general. Right now the consumer side of our renegotiated debt portfolio is 85% of the total portfolio. We don’t break it down, Tony, by region
componenttext:
There’s a lot in those questions, but let me just stay with the delinquency rate on the renegotiated debt in general. Right now the consumer side of our renegotiated debt portfolio is 85% of the total portfolio. We don’t break it down, Tony, by region, but I think you can look at a residential portfolio and the non-performing loans and the charge-offs that we’ve taken and assume that the greater portion of that would be in Arizona.
Where we are in that process, we have seen a slowdown in the inflows into renegotiated loans on the consumer side over the past quarter. We’ll be reevaluating the calendar year renegotiated debt during the first quarter, and we’ll likely move some of that out of that classification in the first quarter, but where we are in that, unemployment rate is still 10%, and our best estimate would be that it’s going to be that way for awhile.
So we continue to see a need from our borrowers to where they’ve got employment issues, where they’re going to come in and want to work through with us on some level of renegotiation of the mortgage loans. So I think we’ll see a continuation of that throughout the year.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, one final quick one for you, it seems compensation of the last couple of quarters has been down a bit. What should we expect there I guess in run rate?
componenttext: Greg, one final quick one for you, it seems compensation of the last couple of quarters has been down a bit. What should we expect there I guess in run rate?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think compensation has been down a little bit. I think, really, let me answer your question more with a perspective of overall expenses. We’ll put those credit expenses aside. I would expect that we would see the overall expense base remain rela
componenttext:
Well, I think compensation has been down a little bit. I think, really, let me answer your question more with a perspective of overall expenses. We’ll put those credit expenses aside. I would expect that we would see the overall expense base remain relatively stable. So I’m thinking in terms of salaries, occupancy, etc. as we’re going forward.
Just a follow up to Tony’s earlier question about the deferred tax asset, just in general terms, a little bit more than half of the deferred tax asset is related to the allowance. Operator, we’re ready for the next question.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Bob Patten - Morgan Keegan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Bob Patten - Morgan Keegan.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been asked, but, Greg, can you give a little color on the margin? Obviously, the jump this quarter was good, but we’re not going to expect that going forward, but what is your view of inflows slowing down, liquidity being used
componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked, but, Greg, can you give a little color on the margin? Obviously, the jump this quarter was good, but we’re not going to expect that going forward, but what is your view of inflows slowing down, liquidity being used up and so forth what’s just ops on the margin?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Continue to believe that we have a number of positive building blocks with the margin, whether that is using liquidity and getting a return on that, whether it is the improvement in asset quality, and at the same time we still have the competitive pressur
componenttext:
Continue to believe that we have a number of positive building blocks with the margin, whether that is using liquidity and getting a return on that, whether it is the improvement in asset quality, and at the same time we still have the competitive pressures that you have in the market everyday and we still have $2 billion of non-performing loans. So those are still headwinds.
We like a lot of the core building blocks that we’ve seen in the market, whether it’s what we see in lending relationships and certainly with deposit composition as well. So our comment in the script was we expect to see the margin to continue trending upwards slightly, but we think there is a lot of building block to support that.

componenttext: You guys ready to call peak and NPA formation?

componenttext: Bob, you know me, I’m only going to do that in the rearview mirror, but we certainly like the trends that we’ve seen.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: On page six, it looks like you’ve written down your non-performing loans by about 27%. How does that compare to the marks you’re taking on the loan sales?
componenttext: On page six, it looks like you’ve written down your non-performing loans by about 27%. How does that compare to the marks you’re taking on the loan sales?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we don’t disclose the marks on the loan sales that we’re taking. Obviously, it’s higher than that number. The one thing I would say, as that in general, over the last three to four quarters, the market really hasn’t changed relative to the c
componenttext: Well, we don’t disclose the marks on the loan sales that we’re taking. Obviously, it’s higher than that number. The one thing I would say, as that in general, over the last three to four quarters, the market really hasn’t changed relative to the commercial side of it. Mark mentioned before about the residential sale improved a little bit quarter over quarter, but in general we continue to see the same level of charge offs on the commercial related loan sales.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then the other question I had just probably more broadly on commercial real estate, obviously a lot of people talking the about the lack of availability of credit on CRE. I know you guys went through and sort of described each of the different sub categor
componenttext:
Then the other question I had just probably more broadly on commercial real estate, obviously a lot of people talking the about the lack of availability of credit on CRE. I know you guys went through and sort of described each of the different sub categories of CRE saying everything was very, very weak, but you still expect balances to be flat.
I think all things considered to get those flat balances. I mean, how are you guys addressing your new loans or even loans coming up for renewal? Is it extending existing loans because they can’t get take out financing? Are you writing new originations? Like how much of that is sort of in flows and outflow into the overall CRE balances?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would answer that in a couple ways. One is that we’re not originating new commercial real estate loans. It would be very rare that we would have any origination going on right now. Then there’s a couple pieces to your question. One is, if we see an
componenttext:
I would answer that in a couple ways. One is that we’re not originating new commercial real estate loans. It would be very rare that we would have any origination going on right now. Then there’s a couple pieces to your question. One is, if we see an increase in our commercial real estate balances in large part will be due to loans that are coming out of construction and going into some level of amortization, which is the first part of your question.
So how are we handling those because there’s no secondary mark, what we’re doing as they complete construction, we’re looking at the available cash flow and really solving for that cash flow. We want to be paid a market rate of interest. How much of that cash flow can be available to start reducing the principal. We’ve been very consistent with what we’ve been doing now for well over a year in handling that after the secondary market wept away.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010

componenttext: Couple questions, one more detailed and one more general in nature. Can you guys just remind me of what did you in ‘05 in tightening some of the underwriting standards of the residential land lending and maybe give me an idea of the difference in performance as a result of that?

componenttext: I mean the general comment would be that we increased the FICO scores, and we’re looking at very carefully at that point, but just different metrics we used to tighten the underwriting guidelines at that point, but my sense would be it’s primarily FICO driven at that point.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The reason I asked about that, it looks like we’re probably in the early stages of hitting three years on the timeframe when you started to tighten and curious if you expect the performance to be a bit better when these loans start to hit their three ye
componenttext: The reason I asked about that, it looks like we’re probably in the early stages of hitting three years on the timeframe when you started to tighten and curious if you expect the performance to be a bit better when these loans start to hit their three year balloon or three year ARM reset?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the land portfolio, we’ve had three year renewals. Now for this would be our third year in a row that we’ve done it. In large part, remember that portfolio, the delinquency on that portfolio is still less than 20%. It continues to bear a lot of our
componenttext: On the land portfolio, we’ve had three year renewals. Now for this would be our third year in a row that we’ve done it. In large part, remember that portfolio, the delinquency on that portfolio is still less than 20%. It continues to bear a lot of our attention, however, just the nature of the loans-to-value on that, but we’re working through it. The delinquency is less than 20% of that portfolio.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there a difference in the performance of a balloon versus an ARM, in terms of when they come up for renewal?
componenttext: Is there a difference in the performance of a balloon versus an ARM, in terms of when they come up for renewal?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not really. I mean, we’re still looking at the same metrics. It’s about somebody’s ability to pay, and then you’re looking at what the loan to value is on a property.
componenttext: Not really. I mean, we’re still looking at the same metrics. It’s about somebody’s ability to pay, and then you’re looking at what the loan to value is on a property.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then the other question I had for Mark Hogan, it’s just maybe a little bigger picture. We’ve talked lot about Arizona and Florida and whatnot, but can you maybe give us one or two bullet points on how you view the health of each of your major markets,
componenttext: Then the other question I had for Mark Hogan, it’s just maybe a little bigger picture. We’ve talked lot about Arizona and Florida and whatnot, but can you maybe give us one or two bullet points on how you view the health of each of your major markets, from the non-performing tables it looks like maybe Missouri and Kansas issue that I suspect that’s more of an acquisition related issue than anything else, but maybe give us a couple bullet points in the major markets?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Greg. I’ll walk through some of those very quickly. When we think about the Wisconsin market, which is of course 40% of our business. Although, we certainly see the signs of the economic stress in this market, total non-accrual loans in this mar
componenttext:
This is Greg. I’ll walk through some of those very quickly. When we think about the Wisconsin market, which is of course 40% of our business. Although, we certainly see the signs of the economic stress in this market, total non-accrual loans in this market are only 2.4% of the Wisconsin loan portfolio, so relatively happy with that performance and that is an improvement versus where we were last quarter.
Minneapolis non-performing loans are a little bit higher, but again, really like the fundamental trends we’ve seen there matter effect non-performing loans in Minneapolis improved by about half 0.5% in the course of the last quarter.
The St. Louis market non-performing loans and credit quality, again shows sign of the economic downturn and some of those signs of stress, but St. Louis and Indianapolis, have both performed well through the cycle. In terms of our core Midwest markets, we see a little bit more stress in the Kansas City market just to be fair that portfolio was a little bit more dependent on the construction category as well.
Going to transition here, just the general economic trends, and in particular, think about some of the beige book data that comes out for the Kansas City marketplace, generally, the economic downturn in many ways hasn’t hit Kansas City as badly. So, we see a great opportunity in that market as we go forward. So, hopefully that covers your questions on core Midwest markets.
Indy very similar to St. Louis I sort of rolled that in very happy with the credit quality trends that we’ve seen in that market. The team there has done quite well. As a matter of fact, non-performing loans in Indiana today are running at 2.2%. So, very happy with those trends as well.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would just add one comment to what Greg mentioned, and that is Wisconsin over a long period of time, is cyclical by nature, really by industry and we would view our C&I borrowers, over any period of time, they’ve gone through cycles, not like the one
componenttext:
I would just add one comment to what Greg mentioned, and that is Wisconsin over a long period of time, is cyclical by nature, really by industry and we would view our C&I borrowers, over any period of time, they’ve gone through cycles, not like the one we’re in right now.
We believe one of the reasons that we’re seeing the lower level of non-performers it just a fact that these a lot of our borrowers have been through this before, and very early in the cycle they took very quick actions, whether it was to employment or cutting back capital expenditure, whatever it might be and the decisions that they made a year and a half and two years ago are really paying off for them right now and I think it’s one of the reasons that we’re seeing reduced level of non-performers in Wisconsin.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Erika Penala - UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Erika Penala - UBS.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: You spoke generally about the trends you’re seeing in terms of delinquencies. In the consumer part of your renegotiated loan bucket, but could you share with us specifically what redefault rates you’re seeing so far?
componenttext: You spoke generally about the trends you’re seeing in terms of delinquencies. In the consumer part of your renegotiated loan bucket, but could you share with us specifically what redefault rates you’re seeing so far?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we’re seeing in terms of redefault rates and particularly let me focus on the single family mortgages, we’re seeing redefault rates, they certainly vary a little bit, based on the individual vintages, since we do look at these on a monthly vintag
componenttext:
What we’re seeing in terms of redefault rates and particularly let me focus on the single family mortgages, we’re seeing redefault rates, they certainly vary a little bit, based on the individual vintages, since we do look at these on a monthly vintage basis, but total redefault rates for single family mortgages for retail are running at the moment kind of in the teens. We expect those numbers will have move up, but remember the national averages, when we see that, I think it’s either the OTS or OCC data, are running in the high 50s if not low 60s.
So we will see ours move up, but we don’t expect we’ll get near there. One of the reasons that we have that confidence is just because a borrower signs of the paperwork that makes a loan renegotiated, if you will, from a legal perspective, we don’t change it in terms of our classifications until that borrowers current for three payments. So, that changes the redefault rate in comparison to what others might report. So, it’s just one way we’re trying to be conservative on that item.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: On back to the commercial real estate bucket, I notice that you have about $220 million in lodging NPLs and this is up a bit from last quarter. Could you tell us how many relationships are in that non-performing bucket for launching and what the geographi
componenttext: On back to the commercial real estate bucket, I notice that you have about $220 million in lodging NPLs and this is up a bit from last quarter. Could you tell us how many relationships are in that non-performing bucket for launching and what the geographical of those properties?

componenttext: It’s geographically fairly dispersed, but the properties that we move from renegotiated into non-performing would account for 170 million of that. So, that’s in the hospitality side.

componenttext: How many relationships are in that bucket?

componenttext: There are seven or eight in 170.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on the question on DTAs, I was just wondering what circumstances would have to occur for you to start for the DTA for you to start allowing back the DTA into the tier 1 calculation?
componenttext: Just to follow up on the question on DTAs, I was just wondering what circumstances would have to occur for you to start for the DTA for you to start allowing back the DTA into the tier 1 calculation?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of allowing back the DTA into the tier 1 calculation, it really comes down to when we look forward and projecting a sustained level of profitability and with a very high degree of confidence. So at that point, we would expect to start bringing th
componenttext: In terms of allowing back the DTA into the tier 1 calculation, it really comes down to when we look forward and projecting a sustained level of profitability and with a very high degree of confidence. So at that point, we would expect to start bringing the DTA back into capital on a quarter-by-quarter basis, depending on what that analysis shows us, but we’ll take a very conservative look at that before we start bringing it in.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It would be sort of a more gradual process?
componenttext: It would be sort of a more gradual process?

componenttextpreview: It’s not a lump sum. I’d be fine, if they changed the rules for it.
componenttext: It’s not a lump sum. I’d be fine, if they changed the rules for it.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I first wanted to follow up just on Greg’s comments looking for stability of inflows into non-accrual. Just looking at that time decline in the delinquent loan balances, do you think that could fall off pretty quickly for your expectations for a more gr
componenttext: I first wanted to follow up just on Greg’s comments looking for stability of inflows into non-accrual. Just looking at that time decline in the delinquent loan balances, do you think that could fall off pretty quickly for your expectations for a more gradual improvement from this $940 million number?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, when we look at the $940 million, we do segregate that because $170 million of that $940 million is this one relationship related relationships that we’ve been talking the about. So when we look at that core level of inflows, you’ve seen it fal
componenttext:
Again, when we look at the $940 million, we do segregate that because $170 million of that $940 million is this one relationship related relationships that we’ve been talking the about. So when we look at that core level of inflows, you’ve seen it fall from $843 million to about $773 million in the course of the quarter.
So I’d love to have after perfect crystal ball in terms of what the economy is going to do. When we look at what inflow levels were going back in history, there’s certainly opportunity for to the comedown, but I need a good crystal ball in terms of the economy he to actually project how quick the descent will bin terms of inflows.

So we’re down maybe, I guess 6% in terms of earning assets. Where would you expect the balance sheet to trough or what sort of decline are we looking for in aggregate?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’m not going to give too much guidance on this. We’ve already commented that we expect C&I loans to contract until the economy recovers. We’ve talked about CRE remaining kind of in the same ballpark that it’s bin, although as Mark Hogan mentioned
componenttext:
I’m not going to give too much guidance on this. We’ve already commented that we expect C&I loans to contract until the economy recovers. We’ve talked about CRE remaining kind of in the same ballpark that it’s bin, although as Mark Hogan mentioned, these are largely amortizing loans in the commercial real estate portfolio.
For the near term, we’re going to continue selling our one to four originations into the secondary market. If I had to hazard a guess and it’s not going to be a lot more than a guess, probably would expect that the balance sheet would continue to contract, but also begin rebounding in the course of 2010.

I’m not going to go through that level of segregation on the call. We’d have to break things out into some pretty fine detail. We did mention this early, we would expect those numbers to start coming down as a combination of the non-performing loan formation and then just the impact of that going through the pipeline should help as well as just better stability on real estate related prices in the market today and if nothing else just helps the sustained accuracy overtime in terms of our marks.
So alright, well thank you, everybody. Appreciate everybody calling in and asking your questions today. Of course, we will be available to answer further questions subsequent to the call. So everybody have a good day, and thanks for your interest in M&I today.
