headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to M&I's Fourth Quarter 2009 Results Conference Call. My name is Stephanie, and I will be your conference operator today. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce Dave Urban, Director of Investor Relations at M&I. Sir, you may be
componenttext: Welcome to M&I's Fourth Quarter 2009 Results Conference Call. My name is Stephanie, and I will be your conference operator today. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce Dave Urban, Director of Investor Relations at M&I. Sir, you may begin your conference.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to M&I's Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. The presenters for today's call will be Mark Furlong, our Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Smith, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the fourth quarter financial resu
componenttext: Thank you, and welcome to M&I's Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. The presenters for today's call will be Mark Furlong, our Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Smith, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the fourth quarter financial results. At the end of our prepared remarks, Mark, Greg and Mark Hogan, our Chief Credit Officer, will be available for your questions. Before we begin, let me make a few preliminary comments. If you have not read our earnings release, you may access it along with supplemental financial information from the Investor Relations section of our website at www.micorp.com. Also before we start, I would like to mention that comments made during this call contain forward-looking statements concerning M&I's future operations and financial results. Such statements are subject to important factors which could cause M&I's actual results to differ materially from those anticipated by the forward-looking statements. These factors are described in M&I's most recent Form 10-K and M&I's other SEC filings. Such factors are incorporated herein by reference. For a reconciliation of any non-GAAP financial measures mentioned in this presentation to the most comparable financial measures calculated in accordance with GAAP, please refer to M&I's website at www.micorp.com. And now, I will turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. As you can see from our results, we continue to remain aggressive in dealing with tough credit issues. Though elevated levels of charge-offs will continue for the next couple of quarters, barring something unforeseen taking place in the econ
componenttext: Thanks, Dave. As you can see from our results, we continue to remain aggressive in dealing with tough credit issues. Though elevated levels of charge-offs will continue for the next couple of quarters, barring something unforeseen taking place in the economy, we do expect charge-offs to start to decline in 2010. We will continue to have some relationships that we need to work through at the end of the recession, but the likelihood of a real estate project surviving today is a great deal different than two years ago. We're most likely at a turning point in credit quality, though another quarter too is needed to validate that condition.As Greg Smith will review with you in a couple of minutes, early-stage delinquency continues to improve such as loans 30 to 89 days delinquent are now at their lowest levels since 2007. This is probably our best gauge of future charge-offs. A great deal of attention is being devoted to what may occur with commercial real estate this year and over the next two to three years. Although our delinquency in commercial real estate is higher than in 2007, the trend is toward a decline in delinquency the last two quarters.We remain optimistic though focused on this portfolio, particularly as we finished a review of all loans greater than $1 million in December. We have no expectations that our commercial real estate portfolio will perform in any way comparable to what we've seen with construction and development. Our settlement risk that are due to the small average size of our loans, our concentration in the Midwest and the extent of cash flow stabilization in this book of business. I'm sure we'll have some issues over time, but we expect them to be manageable. As we move into 2010, we've intended to leave no struggling assets unaddressed. In addition to significant charge-offs on our portfolio over the last two years, we've sold $2 billion of underperforming loans. We will continue to sell these loans, but we expect the pace to slow.We saw some improvement in pricing this quarter, which is to be expected as real estate values begin to stabilize. We feel the same way about properties we've taken into owned real estate. On the commercial side of REO, we have three completed projects in the process of being leased up, at aggregate about $80 million. We've just written down about 25%. On the consumer side, the small number of homes we own are being carried at approximately 62% of unpaid balance. And the residential lots are being carried at 30% of unpaid balance. The point in saying that is to reinforce that we're dressing every matter in the same manner. We're glad to put these last two years behind us. And though the economy still creates some uncertainty, we feel like we're well positioned to remain strong as the credit cycle winds down.There's several positive indicators about the underlying strength of M&I, and Greg will share some of the metrics on these non-credit aspects of our business to reinforce our sentiments. With that, let me turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. By now, you've had an opportunity to see our press release and supplemental financial information. We have included detailed credit quality slides on our website. You may want to have these p
componenttext: Thank you, Mark, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. By now, you've had an opportunity to see our press release and supplemental financial information. We have included detailed credit quality slides on our website. You may want to have these printed out and available for our credit quality discussion.Although our fourth quarter results continue to reflect the challenging operating environment that has confronted banks, our results provide us building confidence that a recovery is underway at M&I. Our credit quality trends continue to benefit from our aggressive approach to non-performing loan identification and resolution, as is shown by: Continued favorable trends in loans going on to non-performing status; continued improvement in early-stage delinquencies, which decreased for the third consecutive quarter; continued improvement in total nonperforming loans, which decreased for the second consecutive quarter. The important items to focus on to better understand our fourth quarter performance include the following: We have continued our aggressive steps to address the largest risks in our loan portfolio, including our Construction and Development business, even though these steps continue to be the primary reason for our loss in the quarter. In addition, we transferred $170 million of larger, previously classified as renegotiated loans to non-performing status as our review showed core performance on these properties deteriorated. We will discuss these loans in more detail later in this call.Despite the migration of these renegotiated loans, non-performing loans were down over $200 million this quarter, which reflects the impact of our continued aggressive non-performing loan workout and disposition strategies. In comparison to the prior quarter, non-performing loan inflows were down 8% when adjusted for the previously renegotiated loans mentioned a moment ago.For the quarter, our early-stage loan delinquencies, those loans past due 30 to 89 days, declined by over 15% since September to the lowest level since 2007. As we have noted previously, we are increasingly comfortable that the pattern of large commercial real estate construction and development charge-offs in Arizona is largely behind us. Since year-end 2007, this portfolio has contracted by nearly 80%, and is now under $300 million.Although we do not believe our construction and development issues are completely behind us, we are encouraged that total non-accrual C&D loans contracted for the third quarter in a row. Our non-performing loans continue to decline. Our portfolio of C&D loans on non-accrual amounts to approximately $800 million, down approximately $180 million from September 30. This decrease is largely attributable to the Arizona market.We have increased our reserve to 3.35% of total loans, or nearly $1.5 billion, and continue to make progress toward our goal of reducing our concentration of construction and development loans, which now stand at 12.5% of our loan portfolio versus 18% at the end of 2008. For the quarter, we benefited from $46 million in after-tax gains from security sales and tendering for our own debt securities. These gains are offset by further aggressive steps in non-performing asset resolution. Our wealth management division continue to grow revenues, as well as assets under both management and administration this quarter, reaching record highs for both. We continue to have a capital base well above any regulatory capital thresholds. At quarter end, our tangible common equity ratio was 8.2% and our Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio is estimated to be 11.1%. During the quarter, we realized 13 basis points of Net Interest Margin expansion, reflecting continued success in improving our funding and lending profiles and the effect of fewer loans becoming a non-performing. We finished 2009 with 106% loan-to-deposit ratio, down from 132% just two years ago.Now for some additional insights into the quarter, and we'll start with the Net Interest Margin. Our Net Interest Margin increased by 13 basis points on a linked-quarter basis to 2.95%. During the fourth quarter, our Net Interest Margin benefited from credit quality improvement and the restructuring and/or retiring of certain debt instruments. Despite recent asset quality improvements, our margin continues to be negatively impacted by non-performing assets. The negative impact is 25 basis points in total, and 13 basis points over the fourth quarter of 2007. We expect that the Net Interest Margin will trend upward slightly for the near-term as we anticipate additional favorable results from the restructuring activities late in the quarter and further improvements in credit quality.Like the industry in general, we expect to be challenged by competitive pricing, the impact of deposit and loan pricing floors, the movement of new and existing deposits into lower spread, higher-yielding products, wholesale funding spreads and, of course, the yield curve. There continue to be many variables that impact margin. It is difficult to project this one data point, given the current interest rate volatility occurring in the market.Now moving on to wealth management. In spite of market volatility, revenues increased 5% on a linked-quarter basis and 9% compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. Expanding sales, enhanced investment products and investment performance generated the improved results. Sales pipelines continue to build across our divisions, especially in our institutional businesses, which include our retirement services, not-for-profit and outsourcing lines. Assets under Management reached $33 billion, up 8% compared to the end of 2008. Our assets under administration rose to $122 billion or 17% greater than the same period a year ago. Our asset management acquisitions continue to perform well. Both Delta and Taplin Canida & Habacht experienced new asset additions and growth of existing relationships during the quarter. Our brokerage and insurance division continue to experience good sales flows during the quarter as investors position their portfolios for 2010. Revenues were up 1% on a linked-quarter basis, and up 6% compared to the same quarter last year, reflecting improved investor confidence and greater coverage by our financial advisors.From an expense standpoint, total non-interest expense amounted to $409 million in the fourth quarter, consistent with the third quarter. Expenses for non-performing assets and other credit-related items were relatively unchanged, compared to last quarter, at $69 million. These are largely related to collection efforts and carrying costs for non-performing assets.Although our reported efficiency ratios is 67%, when adjusted for these items and other credit-related expenses, we view our core efficiency ratio to be 56.7%, down 1% from the prior quarter. Nonetheless, particularly in the current operating environment, M&I will continue to be very focused on maintaining our historical expense discipline.  Now moving to our credit quality trends. Non-performing loans decreased for the second consecutive quarter, resulting in our lowest level of non-performing loans since the end of 2008. When coupled with continued improvement in early-stage delinquencies, these trends support our aggressive approach to problem credit resolution. Continuing with that approach, we increased our loan loss reserves, which now stand at $1.5 billion or 3.35% of total loans. Our commercial, non-construction commercial real estate and consumer portfolios continue to have non-performing characteristics better than the bank as a whole, while our construction- and development-related loans continue to show the stresses of the national housing markets. This stress continues to be most apparent in the Arizona market where our home prices have fallen over 50% from their peak in June of 2006.Coming into 2010, we continue to anticipate a relative stabilization in non-performing loan trends, reflecting sustained improvement in early-stage delinquencies, reduced inflows and continued aggressive strategies to work out or sell non-performing credits. We were pleased that our non-performing loans again decreased for the quarter. Moving in to 2010, we have strengthening confidence that we will see continued credit quality improvements.For the quarter, we realized net charge-offs of $572 million, and we provided $639 million for loan losses. Although these are higher than we initially expected, these levels reflect our continued efforts to proactively reduce our exposure to problem relationships. Importantly, we don't believe that charge-offs and provision for this quarter are indicative of what we expect for 2010. Our quarter-end reserve was 3.35% of period-end total loans, which is an increase of the $67 million from the prior quarter end. In addition to building the allowance, we have identified the specific loss content in non-accrual loans over $1 million and marked them to net realizable value with either a specific reserve or charge-off. As shown in Slide 6, M&I has conducted a specific impairment analysis on $1.4 billion, or 70% of total non-performing loans, to quantify potential impairment. On average, 27% of the unpaid principal balance of these loans has been charged off. Through building the allowance and aggressively writing down problem loans, M&I posts a solid adjusted reserve coverage ratio of 191%.As we look forward, we expect to continue taking aggressive steps to resolve our non-performing loans, the proceeds from which will be redeployed in our business. As in prior quarters, the larger proportion of charge-offs, approximately 52%, were associated with the Arizona and Florida marketplaces. As shown on Slide 31, the net charge-offs by geographic location were $187 million for Arizona, and $108 million for Florida. Otherwise, charge-offs were rather diversified from a geographic perspective. As expected, we are seeing a shift in Arizona charge-offs away from our larger commercial construction credits towards smaller retail-related credits. Discussing our non-performing loan trends. During the quarter, our non-performing loans decreased $205 million, which is 9% below last quarter and 15% below the second quarter. For the quarter, we sold $143 million in larger-stressed construction and development loans. In addition, we sold a $70 million pool of non-performing or seriously delinquent single-family mortgage loans, resulting in a $35 million net charge-off. Like our last non-performing residential loan sale, over 60% of the underlying loans are in Arizona.As in the past, we have moved aggressively to identify potential non-performing loans and the associated loss content. This is supported by the following: 25% of our non-performing loans are current or past due less than 30 days, up from 16% last quarter; of our loans past due 30 to 89 days, which we consider our early-stage delinquencies, $170 million are already non-performing; 34% or $687 million of our non-performing loans are past due less than 90 days. We have already realized partial charge-offs of $810 million against our non-performing loans, representing a 28% haircut. Another way to look at our partial charge-offs is that it represents a 52% write-down on specific non-performing loans, where a direct write-down was deemed necessary. A few comments on our construction and development portfolios. Within our loan portfolios, we continue to focus on our construction and development categories, particularly residential related. Please note on Slide 8 that we have segmented our commercial construction portfolio between C&I related and housing related. This slide highlights the continued strong credit quality profile of the non-housing component of the commercial construction portfolio. Less than half of our commercial construction portfolio is related to housing. As of quarter end, we have $807 million in construction and development loans on non-performing status, representing 39% of our total non-performing loans. As shown in Slide 33, of these non-performing construction and development loans, 50% are in the Arizona and Florida markets. On average, these loans are already heavily reserved or charged down. Clearly, our issues remain concentrated in these markets.To provide a little more granularity on our portfolio of larger construction and development projects, the following may be helpful: We have 27 loans greater than $5 million on non-accrual status, only nine of these are in excess of $10 million, and only one of these is in excess of $20 million. We have seen some stabilization in the residential land portfolio during the fourth quarter as non-performing loans have fallen $64 million. This portfolio is shown in Slides 38 and 39. We have $1.6 billion in residential land loans to individuals and developers, $870 million or 55% are located in Arizona zip codes. A bulk of the Arizona loans, two thirds, are in Maricopa County.The loans to individuals in the Arizona portfolio are relatively modest in size with an average balance of approximately $174,000. We continue to refresh both FICO scores and LTVs for the Arizona portfolio. Individual FICO scores average 736 at the time of origination, and for the performing loans remain above 720 today. Although we anticipate that our non-performing loans in the Arizona residential land portfolio will remain elevated, we believe we will benefit from the fact that we've first tightened our underwriting standards in mid-2005 and ceased new money originations in 2008.Residential lot loans to individual and developers account for $259 million of non-performing loans, of which 47% are based in Arizona zip codes. With regard to conventional mortgages, our portfolio continues to show that individuals are feeling continued economic stress. As we've noted before, we maintain our underwriting discipline through the cycle, have never originated sub-prime loans and have avoided many of the more risky loan products.During the quarter, our non-performing residential loans decreased to $206 million or 4.2% of the residential mortgage portfolio. These trends highlight the benefit of our non-performing residential loan sales completed in December and July. We continue to aggressively monitor and manage this portfolio.Just a couple of comments on our consumer loan trends as the overall consumer portfolio has maintained its non-performing loan levels below those of the overall bank. As of quarter end, only 1.4% of consumer loans were on non-performing status. As we've noted in the past, our credit quality experience with this portfolio has benefited from our historical practice of selling much of our production as we did in 2005 and 2006. Looking forward, consumer non-accruals, including both residential and home equity, are likely to remain elevated, reflecting continued consumer stress. Although we expect that our ultimate losses will remain better than industry averages. With regard to the commercial loan portfolio, during the course of the fourth quarter, we realized $85 million of net charge-offs in our C&I portfolio. These charge-offs are geographically dispersed. Generally, our commercial portfolio has performed relatively well during this cycle, while still showing the effect of the economy. In addition, we realized a decrease of $61 million in non-performing C&I loans.A brief comment on bank holding company loans. As of year end, we continue to retain a portfolio of approximately $550 million, of which 11% is non-performing, and against which we have reserves of 17%. We are adequately reserved, but will continue to evaluate this portfolio critically. Going forward, based on the rapidly changing landscape for banks and the loss of market synergies caused by the spinoff of Metavante, M&I's correspondent banking strategy has been redefined to include only core relationships that are within our banking footprint with the primary focus on fee-based activities going forward.With regard to our non-construction commercial real estate portfolio, we have $13.6 billion outstanding with $3.6 billion in multi-family and $9.3 billion in business real estate. As shown on Slide 16, our business real estate portfolio is generally concentrated in our core Midwest markets, two thirds, with only 17% than our combined Florida and the Arizona market and another 3% in other higher-risk markets. 37% of this portfolio is owner occupied. In the fourth quarter, we saw our non-performing loans in the non-construction commercial real estate category increase $75 million to 4.3%. Contributing to this increase is the review of renegotiated loans that we noted earlier in the call. We performed a rigorous review of our commercial division renegotiated loans, and found that the performance of certain related properties had deteriorated to a point where we felt non-accrual status was more appropriate. With this determination, we moved $170 million to non-accrual status. In addition, we are carrying the loans on our books at 44% of unpaid principal balance through either partial charge-offs or specific reserves.A few comments on our accruing renegotiated loans. Over the past quarter, we have seen a $142 million decrease in accruing renegotiated loans to a total of $793 million. This decrease is largely a result of previously discussed review of certain relationships. On the consumer side, the vast majority of these loans continue to be related to home, land or construction loans to individuals. At quarter end, these categories accounted for approximately $647 million or 82% of the total. Within the consumer sector, our restructured loan delinquency trends continue to perform better than national averages.Over the next few quarters, we continue to expect non-performing loan and real estate owned balances to remain elevated above historical averages, reflecting broader economic stress that we anticipate inflows will continue to slow. We specifically anticipate that the inflows of larger construction credits are past their peak.As I noted in discussing Slide 6, through increasing the reserve and aggressively writing down problem loans, M&I has an adjusted reserve coverage ratio of 191%. We'll continue to violate the opportunity for further sales of non-performing assets and weigh the opportunity versus the cost to keeping those assets for a period of time. Sometimes the best resolution will be to take the underlying property to maximize our interest, which will cause increases to REO for a period of time.This quarter, our REO increased to $441 million, and this is consistent with previous expectations. We have seven commercial properties over $10 million. We continue to expect that REO balances will increase going forward, and view this as a natural progression as we gain control of projects and move towards ultimate resolutions. A few final comments on credit quality. Stresses in the national housing and commercial real estate markets will continue to affect us, and we will continue to address them proactively. We have and will continue to take aggressive steps to resolve our non-performing situation. Nonetheless, should the economy continue to deteriorate beyond our current expectations, our losses could continue. Our non-performing loans continue to be concentrated in the housing construction related components of the commercial and residential real estate portfolios, particularly in our Arizona, Florida and correspondent businesses. Despite a recent increase in Florida, we continue to believe our larger C&D challenges in the Florida and Arizona markets are behind us.Although we are not immune from consumer deterioration, we believe our residential and consumer portfolios will continue to perform better than the industry as a whole. And also recall that our credit card portfolio is relatively small, with less than $300 million of outstandings.We will continue to maintain a strong reserve coverage ratio, and we'll continue to aggressively write down problem loans. We remain committed to returning M&I to a level of solid credit quality, and are hopeful that our declines in non-performing loans, non-performing loan inflows and early-stage delinquencies are all early indicators of achieving this goal.Changing focus to the organic balance sheet trends compared to the same quarter in 2008. Fourth quarter 2009 average loans were $45 billion, which is $4.9 billion or 10% lower than the fourth quarter of 2008. C&I loans decreased on average by $2.2 billion or 14%, as we are seeing lower lying utilization and seasonal borrowing from existing customers than in prior years.Moving into 2010, we expect to see C&I balances to continue contracting until the economic recovery takes stronger hold. On a linked-quarter basis, C&I loans contracted $960 million or 6.8%. Across all of our construction and development categories, we have seen approximately $3.7 billion or 38% contraction since the fourth quarter of last year. This is consistent with our broader goal of reducing our total construction and development portfolio to less than 10% of total loans. At quarter end, construction and development loans accounted for 12.5% of total loans, down from a high of 22.6% in the third quarter of 2007.Non-construction commercial real estate loans increased on average by $1.6 billion, or nearly 13% in comparison to the same quarter last year. This reflects the natural progression of projects to completion and lease up, most of which occurred earlier in 2009.On a linked-quarter basis, loans in this category were essentially flat. Commercial real estate volumes are soft in all categories, reflecting the economy. This is translated into minimal investor activity in new construction projects with medical office being the least impacted. Lack of availability of any financing is significantly impacting this marketplace. Retail continues to soften as expected to do so through 2010, as many retailers have cut back expansion plans. Many retailers are demanding rent concessions on existing leases, potentially impacting our customers. Office continues to soften in all markets. Job loss has significantly impacted this segment in 2009, and are anticipated to do so in 2010. Hospitality softened with the economy in the second half of 2009, and is expected to remain soft. Together, these factors lead to our expectation that our non-construction commercial real estate portfolio balances will be relatively flat for 2010. On the deposit side, we have seen good underlying dynamics this year, with average deposit balances up nearly $1 billion versus the fourth quarter of 2008. Non-interest-bearing deposits increased $1.9 billion compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. This increase is attributable in part to the low interest rate environment and continued confidence in M&I. As we have discussed before, we have reconfigured many of our deposit product offerings. The benefit of these changes are shown by the $1.6 billion of growth in savings deposits and the $1.6 billion of growth in NOW [Negotiable Order of Withdrawal] balances since the fourth quarter of last year. In addition, we have benefited from an improved deposit mix, as our time balance has declined by over $2 billion.A few final comments. As we move into the first quarter of 2010, and to reiterate comments made earlier, we expect our financial results to reflect the benefits of aggressive credit steps that we have taken, but also the challenges of broader financial markets. As you are aware, every economic cycle brings its own set of challenges. This economic cycle has been marked by rapid deterioration followed by more recent stabilization in general economic conditions, a challenging and prolonged low interest rate environment, competitive pricing pressures on many loan and deposit products and a dramatic downturn in the national residential housing markets. As we move forward in this economic cycle, we will continue to benefit from the strength of our balance sheet, the dedication of our employees and the diversification of our franchise. This concludes our prepared remarks. Joining me now are Mark Furlong, our CEO; and Mark Hogan, our Chief Credit Officer, and they can help answer questions. Operator, you may open the line for questions, please.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Craig Siegenthaler with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Craig Siegenthaler with Credit Suisse.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, just a high-level question on reserve methodology. Given that your MPOs have improved now for three straight quarters, can you talk about maybe why reserves are still building at a fairly steep rate? And it looks conservative for investor perspecti
componenttext: First, just a high-level question on reserve methodology. Given that your MPOs have improved now for three straight quarters, can you talk about maybe why reserves are still building at a fairly steep rate? And it looks conservative for investor perspective, but given that your high-severity MPOs, a lot of the construction Arizona loans have just passed through the pipeline. When do expect provisions to start trending under charge-offs, and allowing the reserve to start reducing? And is regulatory discussions one of the reasons that you're still building the reserve here?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a second question, kind of a funding question. It looks like your non-interest-bearing deposits declined in the last quarter. Overall, deposits were okay. But I'm just wondering, what kind of drove that? Was it a client demand from your clie
componenttext: And then just a second question, kind of a funding question. It looks like your non-interest-bearing deposits declined in the last quarter. Overall, deposits were okay. But I'm just wondering, what kind of drove that? Was it a client demand from your clients for higher interests and higher yields? Or what was kind of pushing that?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Craig, that relates to two specific relationships that drove that. Because when you look at the period end, it's really the period-end balances of DDA [demand deposit account] where you see that contrast. We had one large deposit come in for a very short
componenttext: Craig, that relates to two specific relationships that drove that. Because when you look at the period end, it's really the period-end balances of DDA [demand deposit account] where you see that contrast. We had one large deposit come in for a very short period of time at the end of the third quarter. And then those proceeds were dispersed to the various recipients of the proceeds. So that accounts for one component. And then there was also a large depositor of ours that was acquired in the fourth quarter. And their cash balances came down as part of that acquisition. But otherwise, the fundamental trends are very consistent with what we've seen in the past.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The last few quarters, you've had this combination of strong deposit growth, declining loans. And you've been using that to pay off the wholesale funding, which is helping out loan-to-deposit ratios, as you mentioned earlier. But assuming some of the tren
componenttext: The last few quarters, you've had this combination of strong deposit growth, declining loans. And you've been using that to pay off the wholesale funding, which is helping out loan-to-deposit ratios, as you mentioned earlier. But assuming some of the trends continue in deposits, and there's still some decline in loans from here, how should we think about positioning of the balance sheet going forward, in terms of will you continue to pay off debt? Or you can build liquidity? Will you look to add some of the carriage rate, given how steep the curve is right now?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, as we think about our funding profile and our liquidity profile, we continue to really focus on maintaining not only sufficient liquidity, but excess liquidity. Markets are certainly more favorable than they've been, but they certainly aren'
componenttext: First of all, as we think about our funding profile and our liquidity profile, we continue to really focus on maintaining not only sufficient liquidity, but excess liquidity. Markets are certainly more favorable than they've been, but they certainly aren't what they once were. So we're going to continue to position ourselves to being very liquid. In addition, as we think about our profile, we continue to really think about investing shorter as opposed to longer. Because I think the opportunity that will present itself to reinvest in the cash that comes off shorter investments, when you think out, let's say, two years in a time horizon, will be a very attractive opportunity for investments at that point in time.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just separately, I think you've had a moratorium on foreclosures for several months. And I believe it was just extended for another few months. Can you give a sense of how that is impacting the charge-off in end-K [ph] (01:28:19) trends right now
componenttext: And then just separately, I think you've had a moratorium on foreclosures for several months. And I believe it was just extended for another few months. Can you give a sense of how that is impacting the charge-off in end-K [ph] (01:28:19) trends right now?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Generally, it's been an important program. And it's been an important way in which we are working with our customers and our communities. That said, the overall impact had certainly been within very manageable levels of us continuing to sustain this. In t
componenttext: Generally, it's been an important program. And it's been an important way in which we are working with our customers and our communities. That said, the overall impact had certainly been within very manageable levels of us continuing to sustain this. In terms of the number of loans that have actually gone successfully into the foreclosure moratorium, we're still looking at something that's around 400 or 450 through our footprint. So in that sense, it may have some effect to sort of provision and charge-offs, but nothing substantial.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just lastly, disclosure question. The Tier 1 common ratio, do you have an estimate of what that is?
componenttext: Just lastly, disclosure question. The Tier 1 common ratio, do you have an estimate of what that is?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do. In terms of the Tier 1 common ratio, our estimate of that for the quarter is going to be about 7.5%.
componenttext: Yes, I do. In terms of the Tier 1 common ratio, our estimate of that for the quarter is going to be about 7.5%.

componenttext: Couple of questions on Slide 6. The FAS 56 in bottom right, where the cumulative haircut, the lifetime charge-offs moved up to about 31% of unpaid principal from about 23% last quarter. Is that driven by the $170 million in CRE? Or is there something else driving the incremental haircuts?

componenttextpreview: If I looked at last quarter's presentation, the same metrics, the lifetime charge-offs were 23% of unpaid principal. This quarter, they moved up to 31%. Is there something that changed the view? Or is it the addition of the $170 million in CRE restructure
componenttext: If I looked at last quarter's presentation, the same metrics, the lifetime charge-offs were 23% of unpaid principal. This quarter, they moved up to 31%. Is there something that changed the view? Or is it the addition of the $170 million in CRE restructured loans?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Terry McEvoy with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Terry McEvoy with Oppenheimer.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your credit-related, non-interest expense is kind of $69 million, $70 million a quarter over the last two quarters. Could you talk about where you see those expenses headed in 2010? And then maybe remind me in '06 or '07. What was the quarterly run rate f
componenttext: Your credit-related, non-interest expense is kind of $69 million, $70 million a quarter over the last two quarters. Could you talk about where you see those expenses headed in 2010? And then maybe remind me in '06 or '07. What was the quarterly run rate for those types of expenses, to kind of get a feel for a more normal environment?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, just in terms of $70 million in the third quarter, $69 million this quarter. To be fair, $69 million probably came in a little bit higher than we were anticipating for the quarter. But as we continued to be aggressive chasing resolutio
componenttext: Well, first of all, just in terms of $70 million in the third quarter, $69 million this quarter. To be fair, $69 million probably came in a little bit higher than we were anticipating for the quarter. But as we continued to be aggressive chasing resolutions, wound up driving some of that. I think as we look forward, there's a couple of factors that lead us to believe these numbers will be coming down. Number one, as the non-performing loan trends improve, as well as new non-performing loan formation continues to improve, that'll certainly just stem what's going into the pipeline. The other thing is, I think that we would expect that it's going to help us out here is, as home prices stabilize throughout the country, we're now finding our marks on ORE or loans held for sale are holding up better. When you think about the type of price depreciation that we've had in housing over the last three years and the rapid descent of that, you could have had a piece of property that was well marked at the end of one quarter. But if you had the continue of [ph] (01:32:23) trend of home prices going down, you would add an incremental mark the next quarter. So more stability in real estate prices is going to help us get the mark right the first time for the life of the loan which therefore, means the ORE expenses should come down.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk about M&I's ability, interest in FDIC-assisted transaction, especially in and around the Chicago market? In the past, you've always said it's so competitive. You don't feel the need to be there. But as more and more banks fail, hopefully, t
componenttext: Could you talk about M&I's ability, interest in FDIC-assisted transaction, especially in and around the Chicago market? In the past, you've always said it's so competitive. You don't feel the need to be there. But as more and more banks fail, hopefully, that eases some of the competition. And do you see that opening a door for M&I to have a sizable presence in that market?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the second part of that question first. Our view of Chicago has not changed. It continues to be a savage-competitive dynamic in that market. And we'll let others fight that battle out. In terms of FDIC deals, I would say generally, our interes
componenttext: Let me take the second part of that question first. Our view of Chicago has not changed. It continues to be a savage-competitive dynamic in that market. And we'll let others fight that battle out. In terms of FDIC deals, I would say generally, our interest in FDIC deals has cooled a little bit for the moment. As we are seeing these signs of credit quality stabilization or turn, that is something we're going to continue to be focused on. In addition, we're going through a number of a variety of system-type upgrades and improvements throughout the franchise. And we're at that point where we want to make sure we get those right.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010

componenttext: I wonder if you can give us the composition of the deferred tax asset, Greg, at year end, i.e. NOLs, timing difference, whatever. And just maybe some color on your thoughts about that asset, with the discussions you've had with your auditors or regulators. Have you anything new there?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the different building blocks, I don't have those at my fingertips today, Tony. Happy discuss those with you, though. In terms of how we look at the deferred tax assets, certainly, as we've indicated before, as we came up to year end, we were
componenttext: In terms of the different building blocks, I don't have those at my fingertips today, Tony. Happy discuss those with you, though. In terms of how we look at the deferred tax assets, certainly, as we've indicated before, as we came up to year end, we were going to have to give it a particularly thorough review. We have gone through that process and found that, given where we are based on exactly the same types of fact pattern and logic that we've discussed on these calls in the past, continue to find that our deferred tax asset is an asset that does not require any valuation allowance against it. So a lot of that comes from, again, items such as projected utilization of it; de-emphasizing a large business line, in this case, the construction and development component. So in that sense, our logic continues to be the same.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: You've extended the moratorium twice, I think. You sold now, what, two $70 million blocks? And I think the renegotiated resi real estate is still around $400 million. So I guess I'll ask, one, approximately what proportion of the Arizona resi real estate
componenttext: You've extended the moratorium twice, I think. You sold now, what, two $70 million blocks? And I think the renegotiated resi real estate is still around $400 million. So I guess I'll ask, one, approximately what proportion of the Arizona resi real estate has been renegotiated? Secondly, what are you seeing in terms of redefault rates today on renegotiated loans? And I guess maybe, Mark, should answer to this one. Just some sense of what inning it is in that entire resolution process.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Operating expenses. It seems compensation in the last couple of quarters has been down a bit. What should we expect there, I guess, in run rate?
componenttext: Operating expenses. It seems compensation in the last couple of quarters has been down a bit. What should we expect there, I guess, in run rate?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean compensation has been down a little bit, I think. Really, let me answer your question more from the perspective of overall expenses, and put those credit expenses aside. I would expect that we would see the overall expense base remain relativ
componenttext: Well, I mean compensation has been down a little bit, I think. Really, let me answer your question more from the perspective of overall expenses, and put those credit expenses aside. I would expect that we would see the overall expense base remain relatively stable. So I'm thinking in terms of salaries, occupancy, et cetera, as we're going forward.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, can you give a little color on the margin? Obviously, the jump this quarter was good, but we're not going to expect that going forward. But what is your view of inflows slowing down, liquidity being used up and so forth? What's your thoughts on the
componenttext: Greg, can you give a little color on the margin? Obviously, the jump this quarter was good, but we're not going to expect that going forward. But what is your view of inflows slowing down, liquidity being used up and so forth? What's your thoughts on the margin?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We continue to believe that we have a number of positive building blocks with the margin, whether that is using liquidity and getting a return on that, whether it is the improvement in asset quality. And at the same time, we still have the competitive pre
componenttext: We continue to believe that we have a number of positive building blocks with the margin, whether that is using liquidity and getting a return on that, whether it is the improvement in asset quality. And at the same time, we still have the competitive pressures that you have in the market everyday. And we still have $2 billion of non-performing loans. So those are still headwinds. We like a lot of the core building blocks that we've seen in the margin, whether it's what we see in lending relationships and certainly, with deposit composition as well. So our comment in the script was we expect to see the margin to continue trending upwards slightly. But we think there's a lot of building blocks to support that.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Probably more broadly on commercial real estate.  Obviously, a lot of people talking about the lack of availability of credit on CRE. And I know you guys went through and sort of described each of the different subcategories CRE, basically saying everythi
componenttext: Probably more broadly on commercial real estate.  Obviously, a lot of people talking about the lack of availability of credit on CRE. And I know you guys went through and sort of described each of the different subcategories CRE, basically saying everything was very, very weak. But you still expect balances to be flat, I think, all things considered.  To get those flat balances, I mean, how are you guys addressing your new loans or even loans coming up for renewals? Is it extending existing loans, because they can't get take-out financing? Are you writing new originations? Like how much of that is sort of the inflows and outflows into the overall CRE balances?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would answer that in a couple of ways. One is that we're not originating new commercial real estate loans. It would be very rare that we would have any origination going on right now. And then there's a couple of pieces to your question. One is if we se
componenttext: I would answer that in a couple of ways. One is that we're not originating new commercial real estate loans. It would be very rare that we would have any origination going on right now. And then there's a couple of pieces to your question. One is if we see an increase in our commercial real estate balances in large part will be due to loans that are coming out of construction and going into some level of amortization, which is the first part of your question. And so how are we handling those, because there is no secondary market? What we're doing is as they complete construction, we're looking at the available cash flow and really solving for that cash flow. How much we want to be paid a market rate of interest? How much of that cash flow can be available to start reducing the principal? And we've been very consistent with what we've been doing now for well over a year in handling that after the secondary market went away.

componenttextpreview: And then other question I had for Mark Hogan is just maybe a little more bigger picture. We've talked a lot about Arizona and Florida and whatnot. But can you maybe give us one or two bullet points, how you view the health of each of your major market? Fr
componenttext: And then other question I had for Mark Hogan is just maybe a little more bigger picture. We've talked a lot about Arizona and Florida and whatnot. But can you maybe give us one or two bullet points, how you view the health of each of your major market? From the non-performing tables it looks like maybe Missouri and Kansas have some issues. But I suspect that that's more of an acquisition-related issue than anything else. But maybe give us a couple of bullet points in each of the major markets.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll walk through some of those very quickly. I mean, when we think about the Wisconsin market, which is, of course, 40% of our business; although we certainly see the signs of the economic stress in this market, total non-accrual loans in this market are
componenttext: I'll walk through some of those very quickly. I mean, when we think about the Wisconsin market, which is, of course, 40% of our business; although we certainly see the signs of the economic stress in this market, total non-accrual loans in this market are only 2.4% of the Wisconsin loan portfolio. So relatively happy with that performance. And that is an improvement versus where we were last quarter. And Minneapolis, non-performing loans are a little bit higher. But again, really like the fundamental trends we've seen there. As a matter fact, non-performing loans in Minneapolis improved by about half a percent in the course of the last quarter. The St. Louis market, non-performing loans and credit quality again, shows sign of an economic downturn. And some of those signs are stressed. But St. Louis and Indianapolis have both performed well through the cycle. In terms of our core Midwest markets, we see a little bit more stress in the Kansas City market. Just to be fair, that portfolio was a little bit more dependent on the construction category as well. But when you transition here, just a general economic trends and in particular, think about some of the Beige Book data that comes out for the Kansas City marketplace, generally, the economic downturn in many ways hasn't hit Kansas City as badly. So we see a great opportunity in that market as we go forward. So far, that covers your questions on the four Midwest markets.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: How about Indy [Indiana]?
componenttext: How about Indy [Indiana]?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Indy, very similar to St. Louis. I sort of rolled that in. Very happy with the credit quality trends that we've seen in that market. The team there has done quite well. As matter fact, non-performing loans in Indiana today are running at about 2.2%. So ve
componenttext: Indy, very similar to St. Louis. I sort of rolled that in. Very happy with the credit quality trends that we've seen in that market. The team there has done quite well. As matter fact, non-performing loans in Indiana today are running at about 2.2%. So very happy with those trends as well.

componenttext: Well, Erika, in terms of allowing the DTA into the Tier 1 calculation, when we look forward and projecting a sustained level of profitability and with a very high degree of confidence; so at that point, we would expect to start bringing the DTA back into capital on a quarter-by-quarter basis, depending on what that now shows us. But we'll take a very conservative look at that before we start bringing it in.

componenttext: So it would be sort of a more a gradual process?

componenttext: Yes, it's not a lump sum. I'd be fine if they change the rules for it.

componenttextpreview: First, I wanted to follow up just on Greg's comments, looking for stability of inflows into non-accrual. Just looking at the decline in the delinquent loan balances, do you think that could fall off pretty quickly here? Are your expectations for a more gr
componenttext: First, I wanted to follow up just on Greg's comments, looking for stability of inflows into non-accrual. Just looking at the decline in the delinquent loan balances, do you think that could fall off pretty quickly here? Are your expectations for a more gradual improvement from this $940 million number?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, when we look at the $940 million, we do segregate that because $170 million of that $940 million is this one relationship, related relationships that we've been talking about. So when we look at that core level of inflows, you've seen it fall
componenttext: Well, again, when we look at the $940 million, we do segregate that because $170 million of that $940 million is this one relationship, related relationships that we've been talking about. So when we look at that core level of inflows, you've seen it fall from 843 to about 773 in the course of the quarter. So I'd love to have a perfect crystal ball in terms of what the economy is going to do. When we look at what inflow levels were going back in history, there's certainly opportunity for it to come down. But I need a good crystal ball in terms of the economy to actually project how quick the descent will be in terms of inflows.

componenttext: In looking at normalized earnings, it would be helpful to know what you guys are thinking about in terms of further balance sheet shrinkage. So we're down maybe I guess 6% in terms of earning assets. Where would you expect the balance sheet to trough? Or what sort of decline are we looking for in aggregate?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not going to give too much guidance on this. We've already commented that we expect C&I loans to contract until the economy recovers. We've talked about CRE remaining kind of in the same ballpark that it's been in. Although as Mark Hogan mention
componenttext: Well, I'm not going to give too much guidance on this. We've already commented that we expect C&I loans to contract until the economy recovers. We've talked about CRE remaining kind of in the same ballpark that it's been in. Although as Mark Hogan mentioned, these are largely amortizing loans in the commercial real estate portfolio. And for the near term, we're going to continue selling one-to-four originations into the secondary market. If I had to hazard a guess, and it's not going to be a lot more than a guess, probably would expect that the balance sheet would continue contracting, but also begin rebounding in the course of 2010.

componenttext: Yes, I am not going to go through that level of segregation on the call, because we'd have to break things out into some pretty fine detail. Again, and we did mention this earlier, we would expect those numbers to start coming down as a combination of the non-performing-loan formation and then just the impact of that going through the pipeline should help, as well as there's just better stability on real-estate-related prices in the market today. And that should, if nothing else, just helps the accuracy, the sustained accuracy over time in terms of our marks. All right. Well, thank you, everybody. Appreciate everybody calling in and asking their questions today. Of course, we will be available to answer further questions subsequent to the call. So everybody have a good day, and thanks for your interest in M&I today.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to M&I's First Quarter 2010 Results Conference Call. My name is Jodi, and I will be your conference operator today. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce Dave Urban, Director of Investor Relations for M&I. Sir, you may begin y
componenttext: Welcome to M&I's First Quarter 2010 Results Conference Call. My name is Jodi, and I will be your conference operator today. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce Dave Urban, Director of Investor Relations for M&I. Sir, you may begin your conference.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome to M&I's First Quarter 2010 Financial Results Conference Call. The presenter for today's call will be Greg Smith, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the first quarter financial results. At the end of our prepared remarks, Greg
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome to M&I's First Quarter 2010 Financial Results Conference Call. The presenter for today's call will be Greg Smith, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the first quarter financial results. At the end of our prepared remarks, Greg will be joined by Mark Furlong, our Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Hogan, our Chief Credit Officer, who will be available for your questions.
Before we begin, let me make a few preliminary comments. If you have not read our release, you may access it, along with supplemental financial information, from the Investor Relations section of our website at www.micorp.com. 
Also, before we start, I would like to mention that comments made during this call contained forward-looking statements concerning M&I's future operations and financial results. Such statements are subject to important factors, which could cause M&I's actual results to differ materially from those anticipated by the forward-looking statements. These factors are described in M&I's most recent Form 10-K and M&I's other SEC filings. Such factors are incorporated herein by reference.
For reconciliation of any non-GAAP financial measures mentioned in this presentation to the most comparable financial measures calculated in accordance with GAAP, please refer to M&I's website at www.micorp.com. 
And now, I will turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dave, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. By now, you've had an opportunity to see our press release and supplemental financial information. We have included detailed slides on our website. You may want to have these printed out and
componenttext:
Thank you, Dave, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. By now, you've had an opportunity to see our press release and supplemental financial information. We have included detailed slides on our website. You may want to have these printed out and available for later in our discussion. 
Our first quarter results provide us with continued confidence that a recovery is underway at M&I. Our credit quality trends continue to benefit from our aggressive approach to non-performing loan identification and resolution, as is shown by: Continued improvement in loans going into non-performing status, which reached our lowest level since the third quarter of 2008; continued improvement in early-stage delinquencies, which decreased for the fourth consecutive quarter; continued improvement in total non-performing loans, which decreased for the third consecutive quarter. 
The important items to focus on to better understand our first quarter performance include the following. As we expected, our quarterly net loss of $141 million improved to its lowest levels since the first quarter of 2009 driven primarily by credit quality stabilization. We saw a notable improvement this quarter in the loan loss provision and net charge-offs, which were both down more than 25% from the prior quarter. Non-performing loans were down by approximately $100 million this quarter. From our high in June 2009, our non-performing loans are down nearly 20%.
For the quarter, our early-stage loan delinquencies, those performing loans past due 30 to 89 days, declined again to the lowest level since 2007. Our non-performing construction & development loans amounted to $682 million, down $126 million from December 31. This decrease is largely attributable to the Arizona market. We continue to make progress reducing our concentration of construction & development loans to be less than 10% of the total portfolio. Today, the construction & development exposure is slightly less than 12% of the total versus nearly 23% at its high. We have increased our reserve to 3.55% of total loans, or more than $1.5 billion. 
During the quarter, we realized 18 basis points of net interest margin expansion, reflecting continued success in improving our funding and lending profiles. We finished the first quarter with 102% loan-to-deposit ratio, down from 106% at the end of 2009. This highlight the progress we've made since our high of 132% in 2007. 
For the quarter, we benefited from a $30 million after-tax gain due to the sale of our non-core merchant processing business. This gain was offset by continued aggressive steps in non-performing asset resolution. Like many other companies, we were negatively impacted by the healthcare reform legislation, which caused us to take a one-time after-tax charge of $4 million. We continue to maintain a strong capital base, with a tangible common equity ratio of 8.1% and an estimated Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio of 11.1%.
Now for some additional insights into the quarter. First, the net interest margin. Our net interest margin increased by 18 basis points on a linked-quarter basis to 3.13%. During the first quarter, our net interest margin benefited from lower funding costs, partial deployment of our excess liquidity and day count. Despite recent asset quality improvements, our margin continues to be negatively impacted by non-performing assets. The negative impact is 26 basis points in total. We expect that the net interest margin will stabilize for the near term. Many variables continue to impact margin, including competitive pricing and the influence of deposit and loan floors. It is difficult to project this one data point with a high degree of accuracy given the current yield curve and competitive environment.
Now moving on to the Wealth Management business. For the quarter, our trust revenues grew by 9% compared to the same period last year. Fee revenue was up double digits in both personal and institutional trust business lines, while other lines such as securities, lending and outsourcing were down for the quarter. 
Assets under management were up 10% to almost $33 billion at quarter end compared to the first quarter of 2009 and were relatively stable on a linked-quarter basis. Assets under administration continue to grow, reaching approximately $125 billion at March 31 versus $102 billion at the same point in 2009. Compared to December 31, 2009, assets under administration were up slightly. 
Our Brokerage and Insurance division experienced good sales flow in the first quarter. Market volatility early in January impacted overall activity with a rebound later in the quarter. Private banking continued to experience excellent deposit flows reaching record levels for the unit. Overall, credit quality continues to improve as problem credits, primarily real estate-based, are purged from the portfolio.
From an expense standpoint, total non-interest expense amounted to $372 million in the first quarter and declined $38 million from the fourth quarter of 2009. Expenses for non-performing assets and other credit-related items of $47 million this quarter were lower than the prior quarter by $23 million. These expenses are largely related to collection efforts and carrying costs for non-performing assets. The decline was due to lower losses realized upon the sale of OREO properties and lower write-downs during the quarter. Salaries and employee benefits expense declined $7.6 million in the first quarter compared to the link quarter, reflecting normal incentive and employee benefit activity. 
Although our reported efficiency ratio is 58%, when adjusted for these items and other credit-related expenses, we view our core efficiency ratio to be 56%, down approximately 70 basis points from the prior quarter.  Nonetheless, particularly in the current operating environment, M&I will continue to be very focused on maintaining our historical expense discipline. 
Now moving on to our credit quality trends.
Non-performing loans decreased for the third consecutive quarter, resulting in our lowest level of non-performing loans since the end of 2008. Our commercial and consumer portfolios continue to have non-performing characteristics better than the bank as a whole, while our construction & development related loans continue to show the stresses of the national housing markets. This stress continue to be the most apparent in the Arizona market, where home prices have fallen over 50% from their peak in June 2006. We also see some stress in our residential and commercial mortgage portfolios.
We were pleased that our non-performing loans again decreased for the quarter. We continue to anticipate a relative stabilization in non-performing loan trends, reflecting sustained improvement in early-stage delinquencies, reduced inflows and continued aggressive strategies to work out or sell non-performing credits.
As we expected, our provision and charge-off levels were lower than we've seen in the prior few quarters and reflect our continued efforts to proactively reduce our exposure to problem relationships. For the quarter, we realized net charge-offs of $423 million, and we provided $458 million for loan losses. Included in these charge-off is the balance of our largest single non-performing loan at year end, which was a $50 million bank holding company loan that had been fully reserved since the second quarter of 2009. 
In addition to building the allowance, we have identified the specific loss content in non-accrual loans over $1 million, and marked them to net realizable value with either a specific reserve or charge-off. As shown on Slide 8, M&I has conducted a specific impairment analysis on $1.3 billion, or 68%, of total non-performing loans to quantify potential impairment. On average, 29% of the unpaid principal balance of these loans has been charged-off. 
Regarding net charge-offs, although the Arizona and Florida marketplaces continue to be the largest proportion of charge-offs, approximately 44%, they are decreasing in line with expectations. As shown on Slide 32, the largest concentrations of net charge-offs by geographic location, aside from the one bank holding company relationship discussed earlier, were $129 million for Arizona and $55 million for Florida. Otherwise, charge-offs were diversified from a geographic perspective.
For comparison purposes, our Arizona charge-offs of $129 million this quarter compared favorably to last quarter's $187 million and 2009's quarterly average of approximately $215 million. For Florida, this quarter's $55 million compares favorably to $108 million last quarter and is slightly better than the $60 million which was the 2009 quarterly average. As expected, we are seeing a shift in Arizona charge-offs away from our larger commercial construction credits toward the smaller consumer-related credits. From a business line perspective, our Correspondent business realized charge-offs of $66 million this quarter, which included the charge-off of the previously discussed bank holding company loan.
Discussing our non-performing loan trends. During the quarter, our non-performing loans decreased approximately $100 million, which is approximately 5% below last quarter and 20% below the second quarter of 2009. For the quarter, we sold $56 million in larger stressed construction & development loans. As in the past, we have moved aggressively to identify potential non-performing loans and the associated loss content.
27% of our non-performing loans are current or past due less than 30 days. Of our loans past due 30 to 89 days, which we consider our early-stage delinquencies, $171 million are already non-performing. 36%, or $705 million, of our non-performing loans are past due less than 90 days. Our new non-performing loan formation continued to improve this quarter, with $674 million moving to non-accrual status or a 29% improvement from the prior quarter and the lowest since the third quarter of 2008.
We have already realized partial charge-offs of $828 million against our non-performing loans, representing a 30% haircut. Another way to look at our partial charge-offs is that it represents a 56% write-down on specific non-performing loans where a direct write-down was deemed necessary.
A few comments on our construction & development portfolios. Within our portfolios, we continue to focus on construction & development categories, particularly residential-related. Please note on Slide 9 that we have segmented our commercial construction portfolio between C&I-related and housing-related. This slide highlights the continued strong credit quality profile of the non-housing component of the commercial construction portfolio.
As of quarter end, we have $682 million in construction & development loans on non-performing status, representing 35% of our total non-performing loans. We have seen some stabilization in the residential land portfolio during the first quarter, as non-performing loans have fallen $49 million. This portfolio is shown in Slides 39 and 40. 
We have $1.4 billion in residential land loans to individuals and developers. $778 million, or 55%, are located in Arizona zip codes. The bulk of the Arizona loans, 2/3, are in Maricopa County. The loans individuals in the Arizona portfolio are relatively modest in size, with an average balance of approximately $170,000. We continue to refresh both FICO scores and LTVs for the Arizona portfolio. Individual FICO scores average 737 at the time of origination. And for the performing loans, remained above 720 today. Residential lot loans to individuals and developers account for $224 million of non-performing loans, of which 45% are based in Arizona zip codes. 
With regard to the commercial loan portfolio. During the course of the first quarter, we realized $134 million of net charge-offs in our C&I portfolio. Of this, $50 million was the previously discussed fully reserved bank holding company loan. Another, approximately $25 million of C&I net charge-offs, are related to the housing sector. Otherwise, C&I charge-offs are diversified. Generally, our commercial portfolio has performed relatively well during this cycle, while still showing the effect of the economy.
With regard to our non-construction Commercial Real Estate portfolio, we have $13.5 billion outstanding with $3.6 billion in multifamily and $9.2 billion in business real estate. As shown on Slide 16, our business real estate portfolio is generally concentrated in our core Midwest markets, 2/3, with only 17% in our combined Florida and Arizona markets and another 3% in other higher risk areas. 37% of this portfolio is owner-occupied. 
In the first quarter, we saw our non-performing loans in the non-construction commercial real estate category increased approximately $70 million to 4.9%. Like others, we continue to be watchful of this portfolio and continue to stay close to our borrowers. As part of our proactive strategy with this portfolio, we continue to identify problem loans early as is shown by the fact that approximately half of our non-performing commercial real estate loans are current. Delinquencies in this portfolio continue to be manageable, with approximately $160 million of accruing notes past due 30 to 89 days. 
A few comments on our accruing renegotiated loans. Over the past quarter, we have seen a $61 million decrease in accruing renegotiated loans to a total of $732 million. On the consumer side, the vast majority of these loans continue to be related to home, land or construction loans to individuals. At quarter end, the consumer-related categories accounted for approximately $445 million or 61% of the total. Within the consumer sector, our restructured loan delinquency trends continue to perform better than national averages.
Our REO (sic) [OREO] increased this quarter to $454 million. This is consistent with previous expectations. We have six commercial properties over $10 million. We continue to expect that REO (sic) [OREO] balances will increase going forward and view this as a natural progression as we gain control of projects and move toward ultimate resolutions.
A few final comments on credit quality. We have and will continue to take aggressive steps to resolve our non-performing situations. Over the next few quarters, we continue to expect non-performing loan and real estate-owned balances to remain elevated above historical precycle averages, reflecting broader economic stress, though we anticipate inflows will continue to slow. We specifically anticipate that the inflows of larger construction credit, particularly in Florida and Arizona, are past their peak. 
Although we are not immune from consumer credit deterioration, we believe our residential and consumer portfolios will continue to perform better than the industry as a whole. We remain committed to returning M&I to a level of solid credit quality and are hopeful that our declines in non-performing loans, non-performing loan inflows and early-stage delinquencies are continuing indicators of achieving that goal.
Changing focus, the organic balance sheet trends compared to the same quarter in 2009. C&I loans decreased as we are seeing lower line utilization and seasonal borrowing from existing customers than in prior years, consistent with the slower economy. We expect C&I balances to continue contracting until the economic recovery takes stronger hold. 
Across all of our construction & development categories, we have seen approximately $3.2 billion, or 37%, contraction since the first quarter of last year. This is consistent with our broader goal of reducing our total construction & development portfolio to less than 10% of total loans. At quarter end, construction & development loans accounted for less than 12% of total loans, down from a high of approximately 23% in the third quarter of 2007.
Non-construction commercial real estate loans increased on average by $715 million or nearly 6% in comparison to same quarter last year. This reflects the natural progression of projects to completion and lease up, most of which occurred early in 2009. On a linked-quarter basis, loans in this category were down slightly as expected.
On the deposit side, we have seen good underlying dynamics with average deposit balances up $2.2 billion versus the first quarter of 2009. Non- interest-bearing deposits increased $1.3 billion compared to the first quarter of 2009. This increase is attributable in part to the low interest rate environment and continued confidence in M&I. As we have discussed before, we have reconfigured many of our deposit product offerings. The benefits of these changes are shown by the $1.7 billion growth in savings deposits since the first quarter of last year. In addition, we have benefited from an improved deposit mix as our time balances have declined by over $3 billion. 
A few final comments. As we move into the second quarter of 2010 and to reiterate comments made earlier, we expect our financial results to reflect the benefits of the aggressive credit steps we have taken, but also the challenges of the broader financial markets. As our credit quality trends continue to stabilize and improve, our attention will increasingly shift toward rebuilding our profitability profile. Nonetheless, we will not waiver in our credit quality vigilance. 
Every economic cycle brings its own set of challenges. This economic cycle has been marked by: Rapid deterioration followed by more recent stabilization and early improvement in general economic conditions; a challenging and prolonged low interest rate environment; competitive pricing pressures on many loan and deposit products; and a dramatic downturn in the national residential housing markets that has lasted over three years.  As we move forward in this economic cycle, we will continue to benefit from the strength of our balance sheet, the dedication of our employees and the diversification of our franchise. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. Joining me now are Mark Furlong, our CEO; and Mark Hogan, our Chief Credit Officer. Operator, you may open the line for questions.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
