I know you gave some color regarding what was non-performing, but I'm just kind of curious if you could give us something to gauge potential future sensitivity to these types of things. I mean, maybe, a number of credit relationships that are over $50 million or over $20 million? Or anything like that? or maybe segmented by area? Any kind of breakdown I think would be really helpful.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start, Greg, while you're looking up a couple of things and Greg and Mark Hogan will, I'm sure, will have some comments. We have about 14 or 15 relationships that are kind of in that $100 million  to $200 million range. This is the one that's sat o
componenttext: Let me start, Greg, while you're looking up a couple of things and Greg and Mark Hogan will, I'm sure, will have some comments. We have about 14 or 15 relationships that are kind of in that $100 million  to $200 million range. This is the one that's sat out there. Those are little bit larger and they were [ph] with the bank for a long, long time. In that mix, it's kind of a combination of real estate customers that have a lot of income-producing properties, a couple of auto dealers, but performing pretty well this point in the cycle. Obviously, if they reached a little bit of stress earlier in the cycle, they're obviously profitable and doing well and cash flowing today.  So while there is always a strain on a property here or there in one of the larger Commercial Real Estate Developer portfolios, by and large there because they're substantially income-producing, that in many cases, they're actually in pretty good shape. So overall, so they might have one source of [ph] strain, but the others are amortizing principal and interest so we think they're in pretty good shape. Mark and Greg, if you want to jump in and add to that?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: In our Deck of Credit slides, starting around Slide 26 or 27, you can get a real good feel for where the concentrations of non-performers and charge-offs are. We still see a third of our non-performing loans coming from the Construction & Development cate
componenttext: In our Deck of Credit slides, starting around Slide 26 or 27, you can get a real good feel for where the concentrations of non-performers and charge-offs are. We still see a third of our non-performing loans coming from the Construction & Development category more broadly. So that on the one hand has come down, but still, certainly is a much more substantial contributor to non-performing loans than it is to the overall Loan portfolio given the construction is only now 9% of the Loan portfolio. You can also be see the geographic concentration of non-performing loans where, again, there is still, although it is coming down, there is still a disproportionate percentage of loans coming from the Arizona part of our footprint and in then the charge-offs would show up toward the end of Appendix B in these slides. And that again would show as not only the impact of the one hospitality relationship, but also that we still have efficient level of charge-offs running through the Construction & Development portfolio although like the other categories, that, too, is starting to trend down.

componenttextpreview: They are not sitting concentrated in Florida or Arizona or some other heavily-depressed market. They are relatively well diversified and none that are under any unusual amount of stress where there’s been deep devaluation on the markets so a lot of inco
componenttext: They are not sitting concentrated in Florida or Arizona or some other heavily-depressed market. They are relatively well diversified and none that are under any unusual amount of stress where there’s been deep devaluation on the markets so a lot of income-producing in there as well, too, that are cash flowing and doing fine, so that's why we'd say there's not a similar relationship upsize that has a portfolio of properties that is under duress.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to M&I's Fourth Quarter 2009 Results Conference Call. My name is Stephanie, and I will be your conference operator today. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce Dave Urban, Director of Investor Relations at M&I. Sir, you may be
componenttext: Welcome to M&I's Fourth Quarter 2009 Results Conference Call. My name is Stephanie, and I will be your conference operator today. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce Dave Urban, Director of Investor Relations at M&I. Sir, you may begin your conference.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to M&I's Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. The presenters for today's call will be Mark Furlong, our Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Smith, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the fourth quarter financial resu
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to M&I's Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. The presenters for today's call will be Mark Furlong, our Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Smith, our Chief Financial Officer, who will review the fourth quarter financial results. At the end of our prepared remarks, Mark, Greg and Mark Hogan, our Chief Credit Officer, will be available for your questions. 
Before we begin, let me make a few preliminary comments. If you have not read our earnings release, you may access it along with supplemental financial information from the Investor Relations section of our website at www.micorp.com. Also, before we start, I would like to mention that comments made during this call contain forward-looking statements concerning M&I's future operations and financial results.  Such statements are subject to important factors which could cause M&I's actual results to differ materially from those anticipated by the forward-looking statements. These factors are described in M&I's most recent Form 10-K and M&I's other SEC filings. Such factors are incorporated herein by reference. For a reconciliation of any non-GAAP financial measures mentioned in this presentation to the most comparable financial measures calculated in accordance with GAAP, please refer to M&I's website at www.micorp.com.
And now I will turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave. As you can see from our results, we continue to remain aggressive in dealing with tough credit issues. Though elevated levels of charge-offs will continue to the next couple of quarters, barring something unforeseen taking place in the econo
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave. As you can see from our results, we continue to remain aggressive in dealing with tough credit issues. Though elevated levels of charge-offs will continue to the next couple of quarters, barring something unforeseen taking place in the economy, we do expect charge-offs to start to decline in 2010. 
We will continue to have some relationships that we need to work through at the end of the recession, but the likelihood of a real estate project surviving today is a great deal different than two years ago. We are most likely at a turning point in credit quality, though another quarter or two is needed to validate that condition. As Greg Smith will review with you in a couple of minutes, early stage delinquency continues to improve such as loans 30 to 89 days delinquent are now at their lowest levels since 2007. This is probably our best gauge of future charge-offs.
A great deal of attention is being devoted to what may occur with Commercial Real Estate this year and over the next two to three years. Although our delinquency in Commercial Real Estate is higher than in 2007, the trend is toward a decline in delinquency in the last two quarters. We remain optimistic, though focused on this portfolio, particularly as we finished the review of all loans greater than $1 million in December. We have no expectations that our Commercial Real Estate portfolio will perform in any way comparable to what we've seen with Construction & Development. Our sentiments rest there due to the small average size of our loans, our concentration in the Midwest and the extended cash flow stabilization in this book of business. I'm sure we'll have some issues over time, but we expect them to be manageable.
As we move into 2010, we've intended to leave no struggling asset unaddressed. In addition to significant charge-offs on our portfolio over the last two years, we sold $2 billion of underperforming loans. We will continue to sell these loans, but we expect the pace to slow. We saw some improvement in pricing this quarter, which is to be expected as real estate values begin to stabilize. We feel the same way about properties we've taken into owned real estate. On the commercial side of REO, we have three completed projects in the process of being leased up that aggregate about $80 million, each is written down about 25%. 
On the consumer side, the small number of homes we own are being carried at approximately 62% of unpaid balance, and the residential lots are being carried at 30% of unpaid balance. The point in saying that is to reinforce that we are addressing every matter in the same manner. We are glad to put these last two years behind us and though the economy still creates some uncertainty, we feel like we are well positioned to remain strong as the credit cycle winds down. There are several positive indicators about the underlying strength of M&I, and Greg will share some of the metrics on these non-credit aspects of our business to reinforce our sentiments. With that, let me turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and thank you everyone for joining us today. By now, you've had an opportunity to see our press release and supplemental financial information. We have included detailed credit quality slides on our website. You may want to have these pri
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark, and thank you everyone for joining us today. By now, you've had an opportunity to see our press release and supplemental financial information. We have included detailed credit quality slides on our website. You may want to have these printed out and available for our credit quality discussion. 
Although our fourth quarter results continue to reflect the challenging operating environment that has confronted banks, our results provide us building confidence that a recovery is underway at M&I. Our credit quality trends continue to benefit from our aggressive approach to non-performing loan identification and resolution as is shown by continued favorable trends in loans going on to nonperforming status; continued improvement in early stage delinquencies, which decreased for the third consecutive quarter; continued improvement in total nonperforming loans, which decreased for the second consecutive quarter. 
The important items to focus on to better understand our fourth quarter performance include the following: We have continued our aggressive steps to address the largest risks in our loan portfolio, including our Construction & Development business even though these steps continue to be the primary reason for our loss in the quarter. In addition, we transferred a $170 million of larger previously classified as renegotiated loans to nonperforming status as our review showed core performance of these properties deteriorated. We will discuss these loans in more detail later in this call. 
Despite the migration of these renegotiated loans, nonperforming loans were down over $200 million this quarter, which reflects the impact of our continued aggressive nonperforming loan workout and disposition strategies. In comparison to the prior quarter, nonperforming loan inflows were down 8% when adjusted for the previously renegotiated loans mentioned a moment ago.
For the quarter, our early stage loan delinquencies, those loans past due 30 to 89 days declined by over 15% since September to the lowest levels since 2007. As we have noted previously, we are increasingly comfortable that the pattern of large Commercial Real Estate Construction & Development charge-offs in Arizona is largely behind us. Since year end 2007, this portfolio has contracted by nearly 80% and is now under $300 million. Although we do not believe our Construction & Development issues are completely behind us, we are encouraged that total non-accrual C&D loans contracted for the third quarter in a row, our nonperforming loans continue to decline. Our portfolio of C&D loans on non-accrual amounts to approximately $800 million, down approximately $180 million from September 30. This decrease is largely attributable to the Arizona market.
We have increased our reserve to 3.35% of total loans or nearly $1.5 billion and continue to make progress toward our goal of reducing our concentration of Construction & Development loans, which now stand at 12.5% of our loan portfolio versus 18% at the end of 2008. 
For the quarter, we benefited from $46 million in after tax gains from security sales and tendering for our own debt securities. These gains are offset by further aggressive steps in nonperforming asset resolution. 
Our Wealth Management division continued to grow revenues, as well as assets under both management and administration this quarter, reaching record highs for both. We continue to have a capital base well above any regulatory capital thresholds. At quarter end, our tangible common equity ratio was 8.2%, and our Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio is estimated to be 11.1%. During the quarter, we realized 13 basis points of net interest margin expansion, reflecting continued success in improving our funding and lending profiles and the effect of fewer loans becoming nonperforming. We finished 2009 with 106% loan-to-deposit ratio, down from 132% just two years ago.
Now for some additional insights into the quarter, and we'll start with the net interest margin. Our net interest margin increased by 13 basis points on a linked-quarter basis to 2.95%. During the fourth quarter, our net interest margin benefited from credit quality improvement and the restructuring and/or retiring of certain debt instruments. Despite recent asset quality improvements, our margin continues to be negatively impacted by nonperforming assets. The negative impact is 25 basis points in total and 13 basis points over the fourth quarter of 2007. We expect that the net interest margin will trend upward slightly for the near term as we anticipate additional favorable results from the restructuring activities late in the quarter and further improvements in credit quality.
Like the industry in general, we expect to be challenged by competitive pricing, the impact of deposit and loan pricing floors, the movement of new and existing deposits into lower spread higher-yielding products, wholesale funding spreads and of course, the yield curve. There continue to be many variables that impact margin. It is difficult to project this one data point given the current interest rate volatility occurring in the market. 
Now moving on to Wealth Management. In spite of market volatility, revenues increased 5% on a linked-quarter basis and 9% compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. Expanding sales, enhanced investment products and investment performance generated the improved results. Sales pipelines continue to build across our divisions especially in our institutional businesses, which include our retirement services, not-for-profit and outsourcing lines. 
Assets under Management reached $33 billion, up 8% compared to the end of 2008. Our assets under Administration rose to $122 billion or 17% greater than the same period a year ago. Our Asset Management acquisitions continue to perform well. Both Delta and Taplin, Canida & Habacht experienced new asset additions and growth of existing relationships during the quarter. 
Our Brokerage and Insurance division continue to experience good sales flows during the quarter, as investors position their portfolios for 2010. Revenues were up 1% on a linked quarter basis and up 6% compared to the same quarter last year, reflecting improved investor confidence and greater coverage by our financial advisors.
From an expense standpoint, total noninterest expense amounted to $409 million in the fourth quarter, consistent with the third quarter. Expenses for nonperforming assets and other credit-related items were relatively unchanged compared to last quarter at $69 million. These are largely related to collection efforts and carrying costs for nonperforming assets. Although our reported efficiency ratio is 67%, when adjusted for these items and other credit-related expenses, we view our core efficiency ratio to be 56.7%, down 1% from the prior quarter. Nonetheless, particularly in the current operating environment, M&I will continue to be very focused on maintaining our historical expense discipline. 
Now moving on to our credit quality trends. Nonperforming loans decreased for the second consecutive quarter resulting in our lowest level of nonperforming loans since the end of 2008. When coupled with continued improvement in early-stage delinquencies, these trends support our aggressive approach to problem credit resolution. Continuing with that approach, we increased our loan loss reserves, which now stands at $1.5 billion or 3.35% of total loans. Our commercial, non-construction Commercial Real Estate and consumer portfolios continue to have nonperforming characteristics better than the bank as a whole, while our Construction & Development-related loans continue to show the stresses of the national housing markets. This stress continues to be most apparent in the Arizona market where home prices have fallen over 50% from their peak in June 2006.
Coming into 2010, we continue to anticipate a relative stabilization in nonperforming loan trends, reflecting sustained improvement in early-stage delinquencies, reduced inflows and continued aggressive strategies to work out or sell nonperforming credits. We were pleased that our nonperforming loans again decreased for the quarter. Moving into 2010, we have strengthening confidence that we will see continued credit quality improvements.
For the quarter, we realized net charge-offs of $572 million, and we provided $639 million for loan losses. Although these are higher than we initially expected, these levels reflect our continued efforts to proactively reduce our exposure to problem relationships. Importantly, we don't believe that charge-offs and provision for this quarter are indicative of what we expect for 2010. Our quarter end  reserve was 3.35% of period end total loans, which is an increase of $67 million from the prior quarter end.
In addition to building the allowance, we have identified the specific loss content in non-accrual loans over $1 million marked them to net realizable value with either specific reserve or charge-offs. As shown on Slide 6, M&I has conducted a specific impairment analysis of $1.4 billion or 70% of total nonperforming loans to quantify potential impairment. On average, 27% of the unpaid principal balance of these loans has been charged off. Through building the allowance and aggressively writing down problem loans, M&I post a solid adjusted reserve coverage ratio of 191%.
As we look forward, we expect to continue taking aggressive steps to resolve our nonperforming loans, the proceeds from which will be redeployed in our business. As in prior quarters, the largest proportion of charge-offs, approximately 52%, were associated with the Arizona and Florida marketplaces. As shown on Slide 31, the net charge-offs by geographic location were $187 million for Arizona and $108 million for Florida. Otherwise, charge-offs were rather diversified from a geographic perspective. As expected, we are seeing a shift in Arizona charge-offs away from our larger commercial construction credits toward smaller, retail-related credits.
Discussing our nonperforming loan trends. During the quarter, our nonperforming loans decreased $205 million, which is 9% below last quarter and 15% below the second quarter. For the quarter, we sold $143 million in larger stress Construction & Development loans. In addition, we sold a $70 million pool of nonperforming or seriously delinquent single-family mortgage loans resulting in a $35 million net charge-off. Like our last nonperforming residential loan sale, over 60% of the underlying loans are in Arizona.
As in the past, we have moved aggressively to identify potential nonperforming loans and the associated loss content. This is supported by the following: 25% of our nonperforming loans are current or past due less than 30 days up from 16% last quarter. Of our loans past due 30 to 89 days, which we consider our early-stage delinquencies, $170 million are already nonperforming. 34% or $687 million of our nonperforming loans are past due less than 90 days. We have already realized partial charge-offs of $810 million against our nonperforming loans, representing a 28% haircut. Another way rate to look at our partial charge-offs that it represents a 52% write-down on specific nonperforming loans where a direct write-down was deemed necessary.
A few comments on our Construction & Development portfolios. With our loan portfolios, we continue to focus on our Construction & Development categories, particularly residential-related. Please note on Slide 8 that we have segmented our commercial construction portfolio between C&I-related and housing-related. This slide highlights the continued strong credit quality profile of the non-housing component of the commercial construction portfolio. Less than half of our commercial construction portfolio is related to housing. As of quarter end, we have $807 million in Construction & Development loans on nonperforming status, representing 39% of our total nonperforming loans. 
As shown on Slide 33, of these nonperforming Construction & Development loans, 50% are in the Arizona and Florida markets. On average, these loans are already heavily reserved or charged down. Clearly, our issues remain concentrated in these markets. To provide a little bit more granularity on our portfolio of larger Construction & Development projects, the following may be helpful: We have 27 loans greater than $5 million on non-accrual status. Only nine of these are in excess of $10 million, and only one of these is in excess of $20 million.
We have seen some stabilization in the residential land portfolio during the fourth quarter as nonperforming loans have fallen $64 million. This portfolio is shown in Slides 38 and 39. We have $1.6 billion in residential land loans to individuals and developers, $870 million or 55% are located in Arizona zip codes. The bulk of the Arizona loans, 2/3 are in Maricopa County. The loans to individuals in the Arizona portfolio are relatively modest in size with an average balance of approximately $174,000. We continue to refresh both FICO scores and LTVs for the Arizona portfolio. Individual FICO scores averaged 736 at the time of origination, and for the performing loans remain above 720 today. Although we anticipate that our nonperforming loans in the Arizona residential land portfolio will remain elevated, we believe we will benefit from the fact that we first tightened our underwriting standards in mid-2005 and ceased new money originations in 2008. Residential lot loans to individuals and developers account for $259 million of nonperforming loans, of which 47% are based in Arizona zip codes.
With regard to conventional mortgages, our portfolio continues to show that individuals are feeling continued economic stress. As we've noted before, we maintained our underwriting discipline through the cycle, have never originated subprime loans and have avoided many of the more risky loan products. During the quarter, our nonperforming residential loans decreased to $206 million or 4.2% of the residential mortgage portfolio. These trends highlight the benefit of our nonperforming residential loan sales completed in December and July. We continue to aggressively monitor and manage this portfolio.
Just a couple of comments on our consumer loan trends as the overall consumer portfolio has maintained its nonperforming loan levels below those of the overall bank. As of quarter end, only 1.4% of consumer loans were on nonperforming status. As we've noted in the past, our credit quality experience with this portfolio has benefited from our historical practice of selling much of our production as we did in 2005 and 2006. Looking forward, consumer non-accruals, including both residential and home equity, are likely to remain elevated, reflecting continued consumer stress although we expect that our ultimate losses will remain better than industry averages.
With regard to the commercial loan portfolio. During the course of the fourth quarter, we realized $85 million of net charge-offs in our C&I portfolio. These charge-offs are geographically dispersed. Generally, our commercial portfolio has performed relatively well during this cycle while still showing the effect of the economy. In addition, we realized a decrease of $61 million in nonperforming C&I loans. 
A brief comment on bank holding company loans. As of year end, we continue to retain a portfolio of approximately $550 million, of which 11% is nonperforming and against which we have reserves of 17%. We are adequately reserved, but we'll continue to evaluate this portfolio critically. Going forward, based on the rapidly changing landscape for banks and the loss of market synergies caused by the spinoff of Metavante, M&I's correspondent banking strategy has been redefined to include only core relationships that are within our banking footprint with a primary focus on fee-based activities going forward.
With regard to our nonconstruction Commercial Real Estate portfolio. We have $13.6 billion outstanding with $3.6 billion in multi-family and $9.3 billion in business real estate. As shown on Slide 16, our business real estate portfolio is generally concentrated in our core Midwest markets, 2/3, with only 17% that are combined Florida and Arizona markets and another 3% in other higher risk markets. 37% of this portfolio is owner occupied. In the fourth quarter, we saw our nonperforming loans in the non-construction Commercial Real Estate category increase $75 million to 4.3%. Contributing to this increase is the review of renegotiated loans that we noted earlier in the call. We performed a rigorous review of our Commercial division renegotiated loans and found that the performance of certain related properties that deteriorated to a point where we felt non-accrual status was more appropriate. With this determination, we moved $170 million to non-accrual status. In addition, we are carrying the loans on our books at 44% of unpaid principal balance through either partial charge-offs or specific reserves.
A few comments on our accruing renegotiated loans. Over the past quarter, we have seen a $142 million decrease in accruing renegotiated loans to a total of $793 million. This decrease is largely a result of previously discussed review of certain relationships. On the consumer side, the vast majority of these loans continue to be related to home, land or construction loans to individuals. At quarter end, these categories accounted for approximately $647 million or 82% of the total. Within the consumer sector, our restructured loan delinquency trends continue to perform better than national averages. 
Over the next few quarters, we continue to expect nonperforming loan and real estate-owned balances to remain elevated above historical averages, reflecting broader economic stress that we anticipate inflows will continue to slow. We specifically anticipate that the inflows of larger construction credits are past their peak. As I noted in discussing Slide 6, through increasing the reserve and aggressively writing down problem loans, M&I has an adjusted reserve coverage ratio of 191%.
We will continue to evaluate the opportunity for further sales of nonperforming assets and weigh the opportunity versus the cost in keeping those assets for a period of time. Sometimes, the best resolution will be to take the underlying property to maximize our interest, which will cause increases to REO for a period of time. This quarter, our REO increased to $431 million, and this is consistent with previous expectations. We have seven commercial properties over $10 million. We continue to expect that REO balances will increase going forward and view this as a natural progression as we gain control of projects and move toward ultimate resolutions. 
A few final comments on credit quality. Stresses in the national housing and Commercial Real Estate markets will continue to affect us, and we will continue to address them proactively. We have and will continue to take aggressive steps to resolve our nonperforming situations. Nonetheless, should the economy continue to deteriorate beyond our current expectations, our losses could continue.
Our nonperforming loans continue to be concentrated in the housing construction-related in the Commercial Real Estate portfolios, particularly in our Arizona, Florida and correspondent businesses. Despite a recent increase in Florida, we continue to believe our larger C&D challenges in the Florida and Arizona markets are behind us. Although we are not immune from consumer deterioration, we believe our residential and consumer portfolios will continue to perform better than the industry as a whole and also recall that our credit card portfolio is relatively small with less than $300 million of outstandings. We will continue to maintain a strong reserve coverage ratio and will continue to aggressively write down problem loans. We remain committed to returning M&I to a level of solid credit quality and are hopeful that our declines in nonperforming loans, nonperforming loan inflows and early-stage delinquencies are all early indicators of achieving this goal, changing focus to the organic balance sheet trends compared to the same quarter in 2008. 
Fourth quarter 2009 average loans were $45 billion, which is $4.9 billion or 10% lower than the fourth quarter of 2008. C&I loans decreased on average by $2.2 billion or 14% as we are seeing lower line utilization and seasonal borrowing from existing customers than in prior years. Moving into 2010, we expect C&I balances to continue contracting until the economic recovery takes stronger hold. On a linked-quarter basis, C&I loans contracted $960 million or 6.8%. Across all of our Construction & Development categories, we have seen approximately $3.7 billion or 38% contraction since the fourth quarter of last year. This is consistent with our broader goal of reducing our total Construction & Development portfolio to less than 10% of total loans. At quarter end, Construction & Development loans accounted for 12.5% of total loans, down from a high of 22.6% in the third quarter of 2007.
Non-construction Commercial Real Estate loans increased on average by $1.6 billion or nearly 13% in comparison to the same quarter last year. This reflects the natural progression of projects to completion and lease up, most of which occurred earlier in 2009. On a linked quarter basis, loans in this category were essentially flat.
Commercial real estate volumes are soft in all categories reflecting the economy. This is translated to minimal investor activity in new construction projects with medical office being the least impacted. Lack of availability of any financing is significantly impacting this marketplace. Retail continues to soften as expected to do so through 2010 as many retailers have cut back expansion plans. Many retailers are demanding rent concessions on existing leases potentially impacting our customers. Office continues to soften in all markets. Job losses significantly impacted this segment in 2009 and are anticipated to do so in 2010. Hospitality softened with the economy in the second half of 2009 and is expected to remain soft. Together, these factors lead to our expectation that our non-construction Commercial Real Estate portfolio balances will be relatively flat for 2010. 
On the deposit side, we have seen good underlying dynamics this year with average deposit balances up nearly $1 billion versus the fourth quarter of 2008. Non-interest-bearing deposits increased $1.9 billion compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. This increase is attributable in part to low interest rate environment and continued confidence in M&I. As we have discussed before, we have reconfigured many of our deposit product offerings. The benefit of these changes are shown by the $1.6 billion of growth in savings deposits and a $1.6 billion of growth in NOW balances since the fourth quarter of last year. In addition, we have benefited from an improved deposit mix as our time balance have declined by over $2 billion.
A few final comments. As we move into the first quarter of 2010 and to reiterate comments made earlier, we expect our financial results to reflect the benefits of aggressive credit steps that we have taken, but also the challenges of broader financial markets. As you are aware, every economic cycle brings its own set of challenges. This economic cycle has been marked by rapid deterioration, followed by more recent stabilization in general economic conditions, a challenging and prolonged low interest rate environment, competitive pricing pressures on many loan and deposit products and a dramatic downturn in the national residential housing markets. As we move forward in this economic cycle, we will continue to benefit from the strength of our balance sheet, the dedication of our employees and the diversification of our franchise.
This concludes our prepared remarks. Joining me now are Mark Furlong, our CEO; and Mark Hogan, our Chief Credit Officer. They can help answer questions. Operator, you may open the line for questions please.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Craig Siegenthaler with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Craig Siegenthaler with Credit Suisse.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, just a high-level question on reserve methodology. Given that your NPLs have improved now for three straight quarters, can you talk about maybe why reserves are still building at a fairly steep rate? And it looks conservative from an investor persp
componenttext: First, just a high-level question on reserve methodology. Given that your NPLs have improved now for three straight quarters, can you talk about maybe why reserves are still building at a fairly steep rate? And it looks conservative from an investor perspective, but given that your high severity NPLs, a lot of the construction Arizona loans have just passed the pipeline, when do you expect provisions to start trending under charge-offs and allowing the reserve to start reducing? And is regulatory discussions one of the reasons that you're still building the reserve here?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kind of a funding question, it looks like your non-interest-bearing deposits declined in the last quarter. Overall, deposits were okay. I'm just wondering what kind of drove that? Was it client demand from your clients or higher interest and higher yields
componenttext: Kind of a funding question, it looks like your non-interest-bearing deposits declined in the last quarter. Overall, deposits were okay. I'm just wondering what kind of drove that? Was it client demand from your clients or higher interest and higher yields or what was kind of pushing that?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Craig, really that relates to two specific relationships that drove that. Because when you look at that period end, it's really the period end balances of DTA where you see that contrast, we had one large deposit come in for a very short period of time at
componenttext: Craig, really that relates to two specific relationships that drove that. Because when you look at that period end, it's really the period end balances of DTA where you see that contrast, we had one large deposit come in for a very short period of time at the end of the third quarter, and then those proceeds were disbursed to the various recipients of the proceeds. So that accounts for one component, And then there was also large depositor of ours that was acquired in the fourth quarter, and their cash balances came down as part of that acquisition. But otherwise, the fundamental trends are very consistent with what we've seen in the past.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The last few quarters, you've had this combination of strong deposit growth, declining loans and you've been using that to pay off some of the wholesale funding, which is helping that loan-to-deposit ratio that you mentioned earlier. But assuming some of
componenttext: The last few quarters, you've had this combination of strong deposit growth, declining loans and you've been using that to pay off some of the wholesale funding, which is helping that loan-to-deposit ratio that you mentioned earlier. But assuming some of the trends continue in deposits and there's still some decline in loans from here, how should we think about positioning of the balance sheet going forward in terms of -- will you continue to pay off debt or you can build liquidity or you look at the carry trade given how steep the curve is right now?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, as we think about our funding profile or liquidity profile, we continue to really focus on maintaining not only sufficient liquidity but excess liquidity. Markets are certainly more favorable than they've been, but they certainly aren'
componenttext: Well, first of all, as we think about our funding profile or liquidity profile, we continue to really focus on maintaining not only sufficient liquidity but excess liquidity. Markets are certainly more favorable than they've been, but they certainly aren't what they once were. So we're going to continue to position ourselves to being very liquid. In addition, as we think about our profile, we continue to really think about investing shorter as opposed to longer because I think the opportunity that will present itself to reinvest the cash that comes off shorter investments when you think out, let's say, two years on a time horizon, will be a very attractive opportunity for investments at that point in time.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just separately, I think you've had a moratorium on foreclosures for several months, and I believe it was just extended for another few months. Can you give a sense of how that's impacting the charge-off and NPA trends right now?
componenttext: And then just separately, I think you've had a moratorium on foreclosures for several months, and I believe it was just extended for another few months. Can you give a sense of how that's impacting the charge-off and NPA trends right now?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Generally, this has been a very -- it's been an important program. It's been an important way in which we're working with our customers and our communities. That said, the overall impact has certainly been within very manageable levels of us continuing to
componenttext: Generally, this has been a very -- it's been an important program. It's been an important way in which we're working with our customers and our communities. That said, the overall impact has certainly been within very manageable levels of us continuing to sustain this. In terms of the number of loans that have actually gone successfully into the foreclosure moratorium, we're still looking at something that's around 400 or 450 through our footprint. So in that sense, it may have some effect through provision and charge-offs, but nothing substantial.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just lastly disclosure question, the Tier 1 common ratio, do you have an estimate of what that is?
componenttext: Just lastly disclosure question, the Tier 1 common ratio, do you have an estimate of what that is?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do. In terms of the Tier 1 common ratio, our estimate of that for the quarter is going to be about 7.5%.
componenttext: Yes, I do. In terms of the Tier 1 common ratio, our estimate of that for the quarter is going to be about 7.5%.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin St. Pierre with Bernstein.

componenttext: A couple of questions on Slide 6. The FAS 5 section, bottom right where the cumulative haircut, the lifetime charge-offs moved up to about 31% of unpaid principal from about 23% last quarter. Is that driven by the $170 million in CRE? Or is there something else driving the incremental haircut?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I'm missing the question, Kevin.
componenttext: I guess I'm missing the question, Kevin.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, if I look at last quarter's presentation, the same metrics, the lifetime charge-offs were 23% of unpaid principal. This quarter, they moved up to 31%. Is there something that changed the view or is it the addition of the $170 million in CRE restruct
componenttext: Well, if I look at last quarter's presentation, the same metrics, the lifetime charge-offs were 23% of unpaid principal. This quarter, they moved up to 31%. Is there something that changed the view or is it the addition of the $170 million in CRE restructured loans?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So it would not be the addition of the $170 million. We did add additional reserves for those, but they were not included in the charge-offs. So the charge-offs were just about, again, aggressively approaching the portfolio and marking them until we think
componenttext: So it would not be the addition of the $170 million. We did add additional reserves for those, but they were not included in the charge-offs. So the charge-offs were just about, again, aggressively approaching the portfolio and marking them until we think is the appropriate level of valuations.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Terry McEvoy what with Oppenheimer.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your credit related noninterest expense is kind of $69 million, $70 million a quarter over the last quarters. Could you talk about where you see those expenses headed in 2010? And maybe remind me in '06 or '07, what was the quarterly run rate for those ty
componenttext: Your credit related noninterest expense is kind of $69 million, $70 million a quarter over the last quarters. Could you talk about where you see those expenses headed in 2010? And maybe remind me in '06 or '07, what was the quarterly run rate for those types of expenses to kind of get a feel for a more normal environment?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, first of all, just in terms of the $70 million in the third quarter, $69 million in this quarter. To be fair, $69 million probably came in a little bit higher than we were anticipating for the quarter, but if we continue to be aggressive chasing res
componenttext: Sure, first of all, just in terms of the $70 million in the third quarter, $69 million in this quarter. To be fair, $69 million probably came in a little bit higher than we were anticipating for the quarter, but if we continue to be aggressive chasing resolutions, wound up of driving some of that. I think as we look forward, there's a couple of factors that lead us to believe these numbers will be coming down. Number one, as the nonperforming loan trends improve, as well as new nonperforming loan formation continues to improve, that'll certainly just stem what's going into the pipeline. The other thing is I think that we would expect is going to help us out here is as home prices stabilize throughout the country, we're now finding our marks on ORE or loans held for sale, are holding up better. When you think about the type of price depreciation that we've had in housing over the last three years and the rapid descent of that, you could've had a piece of property that was well marked at the end of one quarter, but if you had the continuing trend of home prices going down, you would add an incremental mark the next quarter. So more stability in real estate prices is going to help us get the mark right the first time for the life of the loan, which therefore means the ORE expenses should come down.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk about M&I's ability, interest in the FDIC-assisted transaction, especially in and around the Chicago market? In the past, you've always said it's so competitive you don't feel the need to be there, but as further banks, more and banks fail,
componenttext: Could you talk about M&I's ability, interest in the FDIC-assisted transaction, especially in and around the Chicago market? In the past, you've always said it's so competitive you don't feel the need to be there, but as further banks, more and banks fail, hopefully that eases some of the competition, and do you see that opening a door for M&I to have a sizable presence in that market?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the second part of that question first. Our view of Chicago has not changed. It continues to be a savage competitive dynamic in that market, and we'll let others fight that battle out. In terms of FDIC deals, I would say generally, our interes
componenttext: Let me take the second part of that question first. Our view of Chicago has not changed. It continues to be a savage competitive dynamic in that market, and we'll let others fight that battle out. In terms of FDIC deals, I would say generally, our interest in FDIC deals has cooled a little bit for the moment. As we are seeing the signs of credit quality stabilization return, that is something we're going to continue to be focused on. In addition. We're going through a number of, a variety of system-type upgrades and improvements throughout the franchise, and we're at that point where we want to make sure we get those right.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tony Davis with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tony Davis with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the different building blocks, I don't have those at my fingertips today, Tony. Happy to discuss those with you, though. In terms of our how we look at the deferred tax assets, certainly, as we've indicated before, as we came up to year end, w
componenttext: In terms of the different building blocks, I don't have those at my fingertips today, Tony. Happy to discuss those with you, though. In terms of our how we look at the deferred tax assets, certainly, as we've indicated before, as we came up to year end, we were going to have to give it a particularly thorough review. We have gone through that process and found that given where we are based on exactly the same types of fact pattern and logic that we've discussed on these calls in the past, continue to find that our deferred tax asset is an asset that does not require any valuation allowance against it. So a lot of that comes from, again, items such as projected utilization of it, deemphasizing a large business line, in this case, the Construction & Development component. So in that sense, our logic continues to be the same.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, compensation has been down a little bit. Let me answer your question more from the perspective of overall expenses and put those credit expenses aside. I would expect that we would see the overall expense base remain relatively stable. So I'm thinki
componenttext:
Well, compensation has been down a little bit. Let me answer your question more from the perspective of overall expenses and put those credit expenses aside. I would expect that we would see the overall expense base remain relatively stable. So I'm thinking in terms of salaries, occupancy, et cetera, as we're going forward.
Just a follow-up to Tony's earlier question on the deferred tax asset, just in general terms, a little bit more than half of the deferred tax asset is related to the allowance.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bob Patten with Morgan Keegan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bob Patten with Morgan Keegan.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: But Greg, can you give a little color on the margin? Obviously, the jump this quarter was good, but we're not going to expect that going forward. But what is your view of inflows slowing down, liquidity being used up and so forth? What's your thoughts on
componenttext: But Greg, can you give a little color on the margin? Obviously, the jump this quarter was good, but we're not going to expect that going forward. But what is your view of inflows slowing down, liquidity being used up and so forth? What's your thoughts on the margin?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We continue to believe that we have a number of positive building blocks with the margin, whether that is using liquidity and getting a return on that, whether it is the improvement in asset quality. And at the same time, we still have the competitive pre
componenttext: We continue to believe that we have a number of positive building blocks with the margin, whether that is using liquidity and getting a return on that, whether it is the improvement in asset quality. And at the same time, we still have the competitive pressures that you have in the market everyday, and we still have $2 billion of nonperforming loans. So those are still headwinds. We like a lot of the core building blocks that we've seen in the margin, whether it's what we see in lending relationships and certainly with deposit composition as well. So our comment in the script was we expect to see the margin to continue trending upward slightly, but we think there's a lot of building blocks to support that.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: You guys ready to call peak in NPA formation?
componenttext: You guys ready to call peak in NPA formation?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, you know me. I'm only going to do that in the rearview mirror. But we certainly like the trends that we've seen.
componenttext: Bob, you know me. I'm only going to do that in the rearview mirror. But we certainly like the trends that we've seen.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zerbe with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zerbe with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: On Page 6, it looks like you've written down your nonperforming loans by about 27%. How does that compare to the marks you're taking on the loan sales?
componenttext: On Page 6, it looks like you've written down your nonperforming loans by about 27%. How does that compare to the marks you're taking on the loan sales?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't disclose the marks on the loan sales that we're taking. Obviously, it's higher than that number. The one thing I would say is that in general, over the last now three to four quarters, the market really hasn't changed relative to the commer
componenttext: Well, we don't disclose the marks on the loan sales that we're taking. Obviously, it's higher than that number. The one thing I would say is that in general, over the last now three to four quarters, the market really hasn't changed relative to the commercial side of it. Mark mentioned before about the residential sale improved a little bit quarter over quarter. But in general, we continue to see the same level of charge-offs on the loan sales, on the commercial-related loan sales.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the other question I had, probably more broadly on Commercial Real Estate. Obviously, a lot of people talking about the lack of availability of credit on CRE. And I know you guys went through and sort of described each of the different subcategor
componenttext: And then the other question I had, probably more broadly on Commercial Real Estate. Obviously, a lot of people talking about the lack of availability of credit on CRE. And I know you guys went through and sort of described each of the different subcategories CRE business, basically saying everything was very, very weak, but you still expect balances to be flat, I think all things considered? To get those flat balances, I mean, how are you guys addressing your new loans or even loans coming up for renewals? Is it extending existing loans because they can't get take-out financing? Are you writing new originations? How much of that is sort of the inflows and outflows into the overall CRE balances?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would answer that in a couple of ways. One is that we're not originating new Commercial Real Estate loans. It would be very rare that we would have any origination going on right now. And then there's a couple of pieces to your question. One is if
componenttext: Yes, I would answer that in a couple of ways. One is that we're not originating new Commercial Real Estate loans. It would be very rare that we would have any origination going on right now. And then there's a couple of pieces to your question. One is if we see an increase in our Commercial Real Estate balances, in large part, will be due to loans that are coming out of construction and going into some level of amortization, which is the first part of your question. And so how are we handling those because there is no secondary market. What we're doing is as they complete construction, we're looking at the available cash flow and really solving for that cash flow. How much we want to be paid the market rate of interest, how much of that cash flow can be available to start reducing the principal. And we've been very consistent with what we've been doing now for well over a year in handling that after the secondary market went away.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jon Arfstrom with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jon Arfstrom with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions, one more detailed and one more in general nature, but can you guys just remind me of what you did in '05 in tightening some of the underwriting standards of the residential land lending and maybe give me an idea of the difference in
componenttext: A couple of questions, one more detailed and one more in general nature, but can you guys just remind me of what you did in '05 in tightening some of the underwriting standards of the residential land lending and maybe give me an idea of the difference in performance as a result of that?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The reason I asked about that is that it looks like we're probably in the early stages of hitting three years on the timeframe when you started to tighten, and curious if you expect the performance to be a bit better when these loans start to hit their th
componenttext: The reason I asked about that is that it looks like we're probably in the early stages of hitting three years on the timeframe when you started to tighten, and curious if you expect the performance to be a bit better when these loans start to hit their three-year balloon or three-year ARM reset?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, on the land portfolio, we've had three-year renewals now. This would be our third year in a row that we've done it in a large part. Remember that portfolio, the delinquency in that portfolio is still less than 20%. It continues to bear a lot of our
componenttext: Well, on the land portfolio, we've had three-year renewals now. This would be our third year in a row that we've done it in a large part. Remember that portfolio, the delinquency in that portfolio is still less than 20%. It continues to bear a lot of our attention, however, just the nature of the loan-to-value, on loans-to-value on that, but we're working through it. The delinquency is less than 20% on that portfolio.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there a difference in the performance of a balloon versus an ARM, in terms of when they come up for renewal?
componenttext: Is there a difference in the performance of a balloon versus an ARM, in terms of when they come up for renewal?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not really. We're still looking at the same metrics. It's about somebody's ability to pay and then you're looking at what the loan-to-value is on the property.
componenttext: Not really. We're still looking at the same metrics. It's about somebody's ability to pay and then you're looking at what the loan-to-value is on the property.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the other question I had for Mark Hogan is just maybe a little more bigger picture we've talked a little bit about Arizona or Florida and what-not, but can you maybe give us one or two bullet points, how you view the health of each of your major
componenttext: And then the other question I had for Mark Hogan is just maybe a little more bigger picture we've talked a little bit about Arizona or Florida and what-not, but can you maybe give us one or two bullet points, how you view the health of each of your major market. From the nonperforming tables, it looks like maybe Missouri and Kansas have some issues that I suspect that that's more of an acquisition-related issue than anything else. But maybe give us a couple of bullet points in each of the major markets?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Greg. I'll walk through some of those very quickly. When we think about the Wisconsin market, which is of course 40% of our business, although we certainly see the signs of the economic stress in this market, total non-accrual loans in this m
componenttext: Yes, this is Greg. I'll walk through some of those very quickly. When we think about the Wisconsin market, which is of course 40% of our business, although we certainly see the signs of the economic stress in this market, total non-accrual loans in this market are only 2.4% of the Wisconsin loan portfolio, so relatively happy with that performance, and that is an improvement versus where we were last quarter. And Minneapolis, nonperforming loans are a little bit higher, but again, we really like the fundamental trends we've seen there. As a matter of fact, nonperforming loans in Minneapolis improved by about 0.5% in the course of the last quarter. The St. Louis market, nonperforming loans in credit quality again slow sign of the economic downturn, and some of those signs of stress, but St. Louis and Indianapolis have both performed well through the cycle. In terms of our core Midwest markets, we see a little bit more stress in the Kansas City market. Just to be fair, that portfolio was a little bit more dependent on the construction category as well. But when you transition here just to general economic trends and in particular think about some of the Beige Book data that comes out for the Kansas City marketplace, generally, the economic downturn in many ways hasn't hit Kansas City as badly. So we see a great opportunity in that market as we go forward. Hopefully that covers your questions on the core Mideast markets.  Indy, very similar St. Louis. I sort of rolled that in. Very happy with the credit quality trends that we've seen in that market. The team there has done quite well. As a matter of fact, nonperforming loans in Indiana today are running at about 2.2%. So very happy with that, those trends as well.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Erika Penala with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Erika Penala with UBS.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: You spoke generally about the trends you're seeing in terms of delinquencies in the consumer part of the renegotiated loan bucket, but could you share with us specifically what re-default rates you're seeing so far?
componenttext: You spoke generally about the trends you're seeing in terms of delinquencies in the consumer part of the renegotiated loan bucket, but could you share with us specifically what re-default rates you're seeing so far?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we're seeing in terms of re-default rates, and particularly, let me focus on the single-family mortgages. We're seeing re-default rates, and they certainly vary a little bit based on the individual vintages, since we do look at these on a monthly vin
componenttext: What we're seeing in terms of re-default rates, and particularly, let me focus on the single-family mortgages. We're seeing re-default rates, and they certainly vary a little bit based on the individual vintages, since we do look at these on a monthly vintage basis. But total re-default rates for single-family mortgages or for retail are running, at the moment, kind of in the teens. We expect those numbers will move up, but remember, the national averages, when we see that, I think it's either the OTS or OCC data, are running in the high 50s, if not low 60s. So we will see ours move up, but we don't expect we'll get near there. One of the reasons that we have that confidence is just because a borrower signs the paperwork that makes a loan renegotiated, if you will from a legal perspective, we don't change it in terms of our classifications until that borrower's current for three payments. So that changes the re-default rate in comparison to what others might report. So it's just one way we're trying to be conservative on that item.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And back to the Commercial Real Estate bucket, I noticed that you have about $220 million in lodging NPLs, and this is up a bit from last quarter. Can you tell us how many relationships are in that nonperforming bucket for lodging and what the geographica
componenttext: And back to the Commercial Real Estate bucket, I noticed that you have about $220 million in lodging NPLs, and this is up a bit from last quarter. Can you tell us how many relationships are in that nonperforming bucket for lodging and what the geographical footprint is of those properties?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Geographically, it's fairly dispersed, but the properties that we moved from renegotiated into nonperforming would account for $170 million of that, so that is in the hospitality side.
componenttext: Geographically, it's fairly dispersed, but the properties that we moved from renegotiated into nonperforming would account for $170 million of that, so that is in the hospitality side.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And how many relationships are in that bucket?
componenttext: And how many relationships are in that bucket?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are seven or eight in the $170 million.
componenttext: There are seven or eight in the $170 million.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up question on DTAs, I was just wondering, what circumstances would have to occur for you to start allowing back the DTA into the Tier 1 calculation?
componenttext: And just a follow-up question on DTAs, I was just wondering, what circumstances would have to occur for you to start allowing back the DTA into the Tier 1 calculation?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Erika, in terms of allowing back the DTA into the Tier 1 calculation, it really comes down to looking, when we look forward and projecting a sustained level of profitability and with a very high degree of confidence. So at that point, we would expect to s
componenttext: Erika, in terms of allowing back the DTA into the Tier 1 calculation, it really comes down to looking, when we look forward and projecting a sustained level of profitability and with a very high degree of confidence. So at that point, we would expect to start bringing the DTA back into capital on a quarter-by-quarter basis depending on what that analysis shows us, but we'll take a very conservative look at that before we start bringing it in.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So it would be sort of a more gradual process?
componenttext: So it would be sort of a more gradual process?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's not a lump sum. I'd be fine if they changed the rules for it.
componenttext: It's not a lump sum. I'd be fine if they changed the rules for it.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Alexopoulos with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Alexopoulos with JPMorgan.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I first wanted to follow up just on Greg's comments looking for stability of inflows into non-accruals. Just looking at the decline in the delinquent loan balances, do you think that could fall off pretty quickly here? Are your expectations for a more gra
componenttext: I first wanted to follow up just on Greg's comments looking for stability of inflows into non-accruals. Just looking at the decline in the delinquent loan balances, do you think that could fall off pretty quickly here? Are your expectations for a more gradual movement from this $940 million number?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, we look at the $940 million. We do segregate that because a $170 million of that $940 million is this one relationship, related relationships that we've been talking about. So when we look at that core level of inflows, you've seen it fall fr
componenttext: Well, again, we look at the $940 million. We do segregate that because a $170 million of that $940 million is this one relationship, related relationships that we've been talking about. So when we look at that core level of inflows, you've seen it fall from 843 to about 773 in the course of the quarter. So I'd love to have a perfect crystal ball in terms of what the economy is going to do. When we look at what inflow levels were going back in history, there's certainly opportunity for it to come down, but I need a good crystal ball in terms of the economy to actually project how quick the descent will be in terms of inflows.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know if you could answer this question, but if you look at the magnitude in the comments that you expect charge-offs to improve through 2010, do you think we get to a level this year you could actually cover provision expense with pretax pre-provi
componenttext: I don't know if you could answer this question, but if you look at the magnitude in the comments that you expect charge-offs to improve through 2010, do you think we get to a level this year you could actually cover provision expense with pretax pre-provision or is that a bit too optimistic?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll have to see how we go into the back half of the year. I mean, take into account Mark Hogan's earlier comments about provision versus charge-offs and where some of the opportunities are there, continued strength with net interest margin, et cetera. W
componenttext: We'll have to see how we go into the back half of the year. I mean, take into account Mark Hogan's earlier comments about provision versus charge-offs and where some of the opportunities are there, continued strength with net interest margin, et cetera. We'll just have to see how the economy goes.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Rob Rutschow with CLSA.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Rob Rutschow with CLSA.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have a kind of a broader question, and I apologize if you've already spoken to this, but in looking at normalized earnings, it would be helpful to know what you guys are thinking about it in terms of further balance sheet shrinkage. So we're down maybe,
componenttext: I have a kind of a broader question, and I apologize if you've already spoken to this, but in looking at normalized earnings, it would be helpful to know what you guys are thinking about it in terms of further balance sheet shrinkage. So we're down maybe, I guess, 6% in terms of earning assets. Where would you expect the balance sheet to trough? Or what sort of decline are we looking for in aggregate?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not going to give too much guidance on this. We've already commented that we expect C&I loans to contract until the economy recovers. We've talked about CRE remaining kind of in the same ballpark that it's been in, although as Mark Hogan mention
componenttext: Well, I'm not going to give too much guidance on this. We've already commented that we expect C&I loans to contract until the economy recovers. We've talked about CRE remaining kind of in the same ballpark that it's been in, although as Mark Hogan mentioned, these are largely amortizing loans in the Commercial Real Estate portfolio. And for the near term, we're going to continue selling one to four originations into the secondary market. If I had to hazard a guess, and it's not going to be a lot more than a guess, probably would expect that the balance sheet would continue contracting, but also begin rebounding in the course of 2010.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the second question would be can you give us an idea of what the OREO expense would've been had you not sold loans? And what should we think about in terms of OREO expense in, say, the next four to eight quarters?
componenttext: And the second question would be can you give us an idea of what the OREO expense would've been had you not sold loans? And what should we think about in terms of OREO expense in, say, the next four to eight quarters?

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not going to go through that level of segregation on the call because we have to break things out into some pretty fine detail. Again, and we did mentioned this earlier, we would expect those numbers to start coming down as a combination of the n
componenttext:
Yes, I'm not going to go through that level of segregation on the call because we have to break things out into some pretty fine detail. Again, and we did mentioned this earlier, we would expect those numbers to start coming down as a combination of the nonperforming loan formation and then just the impact of that going through the pipeline. It should help as well as there's just better stability on real estate-related prices in the market today. And that should -- if nothing else, just helps the accuracy, both the sustained accuracy over time in terms of our marks. 
Well, thank you, everybody. Appreciate everybody calling in and asking their questions today. Of course, we will be available to answer further questions subsequent to the call. So everybody, have a good day, and thanks for your interest in M&I today.

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This concludes today's conference. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: Thank you. This concludes today's conference. You may now disconnect.
